chapter.title: 29 Nocardia, Rhodococcus, Gordonia, Actinomadura, Streptomyces, and Other Aerobic Actinomycetes

sect1.title: 29 Nocardia, Rhodococcus, Gordonia, Actinomadura, Streptomyces, and Other Aerobic Actinomycetes

para.phrase: BARBARA A. BROWN-ELLIOTT, ADRIAN M. ZELAZNY, AND PATRICIA S. CONVILLE

sect2.title: TAXONOMY
sect2.para: The word “actinomycete” is derived from two Greek roots (actino- and -mycete) meaning “ray” (and hence also “rod”) and “fungus,” respectively. The anaerobic organisms now in the genus Actinomyces and the aerobic organisms grouped together as the “aerobic actinomycetes” were previously presumed to be related to one another on the basis of shared features of microscopic and colonial morphology. The aerobic actinomycetes, a group for which no agreed-upon operational definition currently exists, are now known to be an evolutionarily heterogeneous assemblage of genera. At some stage, they all form Gram-positive rods, and most of the more commonly isolated species exhibit at least rudimentary branching under certain growth conditions. All genera grow better under aerobic than anaerobic conditions (except for the newly described genus Lawsonella), a feature distinguishing them from most organisms in the genus Actinomyces. Because Lawsonella displays many other traits demonstrated by other members of the aerobic actinomycetes, including being partially acid-fast, this species will be included in the discussions in this chapter. Figure 1 shows the current classification of most of the genera included in this chapter according to the List of Prokaryotic Names with Standing in Nomenclature (LPSN; http://www.bacterio.net/).

The organisms that contain mycolic acids in their cell walls (included in the generaDietzia, Gordonia, Nocardia, Rhodococcus, Segniliparus, Tsukamurella, and Williamsia) are closely related on the basis of molecular genetic studies (1, 2); these mycolic-acid-containing genera appear phylogenetically more closely related to the genera Corynebacterium and Mycobacterium (both of which are sometimes considered aerobic actinomycetes) than to the other non-mycolic-acid-containing genera usually also included with the aerobic actinomycetes. According to a recent classification scheme, these seven genera of actinomycetes, along with the genera Corynebacterium and Mycobacterium, are classified together in the order Mycobacteriales (LPSN). Note in Fig. 1 that the genera in the order Mycobacteriales are at least weakly acid fast, with the exception of Williamsia and possibly Dietzia.

The number of recognized pathogenic species of aerobic actinomycetes has been rising rapidly. However, this chapter deals only with genera containing species of documented clinical significance. Unfortunately, the increasingly fine discrimination of species has made it difficult to delineate important species-specific differences in geographic distributions, pathogenic and other biological mechanisms, disease associations, and antimicrobial susceptibility patterns. This enormous proliferation of distinct species for which association with human disease has been claimed presents several problems for the clinical microbiologist. First, phenotypic testing has been rendered virtually useless for accurate discrimination among species. Particularly for the aerobic actinomycetes, the number of phenotypic (biochemical) tests available in clinical laboratories (and in most research laboratories) is far too small for accurate differentiation among so many species, and often, information on the percent positivity for a specific reaction in a given species is not known. Furthermore, precisely the same biochemical testing format has generally not been employed with isolates of all the species, making the usefulness of multistudy comparisons uncertain. Second, some types of testing, such as analysis of cell wall constituents and of whole-cell sugars, are available in only a few research settings and are rarely of use for species-level identification. Some general information regarding these features is provided herein, but the references should be consulted for performance procedures and additional details. Third, gene sequencing is currently adequately discriminatory, reproducible, and sufficiently available to be useful for precise species identifications in many clinical laboratories. Fourth, while the use of matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) allows the discrimination of certain species, this procedure is adequately sensitive only if the associated database has been adequately validated. Fifth, because of the growing problems with accurate species determinations, the clinical literature is rife with erroneous identifications; nowhere is this problem more apparent than with organisms in the genusNocardia. Additionally, because some species have been described on the basis of only a single isolate, and for others only a few reports exist, little if any meaningful clinical information can be associated with many species names. Thus, when molecular methods are not available, precise identification of isolates may be impossible and, given the current state of our knowledge, is frequently not of immediate clinical utility.

sect2.para: There are a few terminology issues that, while they pertain to all bacteria, seem to cause confusion particularly frequently with regard to the aerobic actinomycetes. First, for every bacterial species, there is only one “type strain,” the strain on which the original description of the species was based. Other strains contained in culture collections that are thought to belong to the same species as a given type strain can be referred to as “reference strains,” but they are not type strains. Second, the term “sensu stricto” means “in the strict sense.” This term, when used with a species name, should be restricted to mean organisms belonging to that particular species as determined by the best available methods. So, to refer to isolates that are “Nocardia asteroides sensu stricto” should mean isolates that by gene sequencing are identical to the type strain of N. asteroides (ATCC 19247).

sect2.title: DESCRIPTION OF THE GENERA
sect2.para: Basic information about specific microscopic and colonial morphologies of the following genera is presented inTable 1; additional information is included in the text below for some genera. For a review of chemotaxonomic characteristics and lysozyme resistance of the genera of aerobic actinomycetes, see previous editions of the Manual of Clinical Microbiology (3). In the listings that follow, enumeration of species within a genus is taken from the LPSN.

sect1.title: Actinomadura
sect1.para: The microscopic and colonial morphologies of organisms in the genusActinomadura, which contains more than 100 validly named species or subspecies, are very similar to those in the genus Streptomyces (Fig. 2A and Band 3A). The colors of the colonies may vary considerably among different species. Cell walls contain the sugar madurose, a feature shared only with organisms in the genus Dermatophilus.

sect1.title: Amycolatopsis
sect1.para: The genusAmycolatopsis was proposed by Lechevalier et al. for Nocardia-like organisms that were Gram positive and modified acid-fast stain negative but lacked mycolic acids (4) (Fig. 2F and 3B). Currently, there are more than 80 validly named species or subspecies in the genus Amycolatopsis.

sect1.title: Dermatophilus
sect1.para: There are currently two species included in the genusDermatophilus. Dermatophilus congolensis, a rare human pathogen, and Dermatophilus chelonae, described in turtles from Australia, are probably not closely related to most of the other organisms considered in this chapter (5). Aerial mycelia may be produced by colonies if the organism is grown in an atmosphere of increased CO2; the organism is facultatively anaerobic (6). The microscopic morphology is unusual and striking; this branching organism develops both longitudinal and transverse septa (Fig. 3D). The resulting chains of coccoid cells may occur in as many as eight parallel rows (7). The coccoid cells may develop into motile zoospores under favorable environmental conditions.

sect1.title: Desmospora
sect1.para: The genusDesmospora currently contains two species, only one of which, Desmospora activa, has been implicated in human disease. Members of this genus are related to species in the genus Thermoactinomyces. D. activa is a filamentous, thermotolerant bacterium that was isolated from the sputum of a patient suspected of having tuberculosis, but it is unclear if it was the cause of the patient’s pulmonary disease (8).

sect1.title: Dietzia
sect1.para: The speciesDietzia maris was removed from the genus Rhodococcus because of chemotaxonomic and 16S rRNA gene sequence differences from other Rhodococcus species (9). Dietzia isolates apparently rarely, if ever, branch, but may show coccal and rod forms. There are approximately 15 species included in the genus Dietzia; however, discrimination among these species may be extremely difficult, even with gene sequencing methods.

sect1.title: Gordonia
sect1.para: Upon Gram staining,Gordonia species appear coryneform and could easily be mistaken for a component of the normal oral biota in sputum specimens (Fig. 3C). The genus “Gordona” (now Gordonia), originally described by Tsukamura, was revived in 1988 by Stackebrandt et al. to contain species with mycolic acids of approximately 46 to 66 carbon atoms in length and a predominant menaquinone of 9 isoprene units. Gordonia and Rhodococcus were also found to be separable on the basis of their 16S rRNA gene sequences (10). There are approximately 50 validly named species in the genus (Fig. 2I and 3C).

sect1.title: Kroppenstedtia
sect1.para: Kroppenstedtia was defined on the basis of an isolate found during environmental screening of a plastic surface in a manufacturing organization, but Kroppenstedtia eburnea has since been recovered from a variety of clinical specimens. There are four validly described species in the genus. However, a recent publication reports two additional species, Kroppenstedtia pulmonis and Kroppenstedtia sanguinis, isolated from lung biopsy, blood, and cerebrospinal fluid (11). Kroppenstedtia species have chemotaxonomic and molecular features typical of members of the family Thermoactinomycetaceae, except for containing LL-diaminopimelic acid in their cell wall peptidoglycan. (Diaminopimelic acid is in the meso conformation in the other members of the family [12]).

sect1.title: Lawsonella
sect1.para: Lawsonella was defined based on the isolation of organisms with unusual growth characteristics from human abscesses. The genus contains one species, Lawsonella clevelandensis, which is a slowly growing (5 to 7 days) organism that requires less than 1% oxygen tension. Members of the species are Gram-positive early and become Gram variable as the colonies age. Phylogenetic analyses indicate that L. clevelandensis is most closely related to Dietzia timorensis. The ecologic niche of this organism is unknown (13).

sect1.title: Nocardia
sect1.para: The aerobic actinomycetes most commonly recognized as human pathogens belong to the genusNocardia; there are over 100 validly named species included in this genus. In direct Gram smears, organisms generally appear as very long, obviously branching, thin, and finely beaded Gram-positive rods (Fig. 3E and K). Unlike the individual cells composing a streptococcal chain, the beads generally do not abut one another (Fig. 3H and O). Particularly when prepared from cultures, smears may show streptococcus-like chains or small branching filaments, probably as a result of the fragile nocardial mycelium breaking during smear preparation (14, 15) (Fig. 3E, F, G, K, and L).

Colonial morphology varies from species to species and frequently varies from isolate to isolate within a species (Fig. 2D, E, G, and L). Colony color may best be seen on the reverse when colonies are grown on translucent media (such as Sabouraud agar), because color may become obscured on the surface by the powdery aerial hyphae typically produced by members of this genus.

A brief account of the nomenclatural history of the designation “Nocardia asteroides” is necessary to clarify a confusing and widely unappreciated taxonomic issue. In 1888, Edmond Nocard obtained an isolate of an organism thought to be the causative agent of bovine farcy, a chronic suppurative skin and lymphatic infection of cattle. This organism was given the name Nocardia farcinica by Trevisan in 1889, and thereupon it became the type strain for both the genus and species. Gordon and Mihm (16) found, using their battery of phenotypic tests, that N. farcinica could not be distinguished from isolates to which the name Nocardia asteroides had been applied. Because of some uncertainty relating to the isolate obtained by Nocard and what was presumed to be the conspecificity of the organisms then known as N. farcinica and N. asteroides, an appeal was made to the Judicial Commission to have the type species of the genus changed to N. asteroides, with strain ATCC 19247 selected as the type strain of the species. The appeal was accepted, but the isolate of N. farcinica was retained as the type strain for that particular species, because not all were convinced that the two species were truly identical.

sect1.title: Nocardiopsis
sect1.para: The genusNocardiopsis was originally described by Meyer to accommodate an organism that at the time was called Actinomadura dassonvillei but that differed chemotaxonomically and in certain colonial morphologic features from other organisms in the genus Actinomadura. The cell wall of this organism does not contain madurose. The substrate mycelium fragments into coccal forms, and the aerial hyphae fragment into variously sized spores (17). Currently, there are more than 60 named species or subspecies in the genus. Species belonging to Nocardiopsis are mostly known for their use in biotechnology as a result of the bioactive compounds they produce (18).

sect1.title: Pseudonocardia
sect1.para: Pseudonocardia species are characterized by the microscopic morphology of their aerial hyphae, which are segmented as a result of growth by budding. Aerial and substrate hyphae are often zigzag shaped (19). A study based on 16S rRNA gene sequences led to the recommendation to combine the genera Amycolata and Pseudonocardia into an emended genus, Pseudonocardia (20). Currently, there are more than 60 published species in the emended genus.

sect1.title: Rhodococcus
sect1.para: The microscopic morphology of rhodococci can range from coccoid to bacillary, depending on species and specimen type and on the stage of growth of the organism. The organisms exhibit a rod-to-coccus growth cycle. Rod forms are best visualized by growing isolates in a liquid medium, and under such conditions, some branching of individual cells may be found (21). Generally, however, the organisms appear as Gram-positive coccobacilli which may be solidly stained or have a beaded appearance (Fig. 3H). Modified acid-fast staining must be performed and interpreted with particular care when dealing with isolates that may belong to this genus, because only a tiny fraction of the cells may retain the stain (Fig. 3I). Modified acid-fast smears prepared from isolates growing on Trypticase soy agar with 5% sheep blood or chocolate agar may appear to be acid-fast negative (22). Rhodococcus species can easily be dismissed as “diphtheroids” because of their Gram stain morphology (Fig. 3H) and their frequent failure to develop obvious pigmentation during the first few days of growth. At 37°C, colonies may be only about 1 mm in diameter after 24 h of incubation. An aerial mycelium is generally not macroscopically visible but may occasionally be seen microscopically (23). There are more than 70 named species in the genus. Kämpfer et al. reported that the type strain of Corynebacterium hoagii (first described in 1912) shows identical genotypic and phenotypic characteristics to the type strain of R. equi. Because the species name “hoagii” has priority as the oldest epithet, the authors propose the reclassification of R. equi as Rhodococcus hoagii (24). The name R. equi is used in this text.
Rhodococcus aurantiacus ATCC 25938 (the initial type strain of the species), which has had a convoluted taxonomic history, has been placed in the species Tsukamurella paurometabola (25).

sect1.title: Saccharomonospora
sect1.para: The species in the genusSaccharomonospora are characterized by the presence of single spores tightly packed on aerial hyphae. The organisms are commonly found in soil, lake sediment, peat, compost, and manure. They are moderately thermophilic, with optimum growth occurring at 35 to 50°C (26). There are 14 validly named species in the genus.

sect1.title: Saccharopolyspora
sect1.para: Species in the genusSaccharopolyspora were initially thought to be related to Nocardia and Streptomyces by biochemical characteristics but are phylogenetically distinct from those genera. The organism was originally isolated from sugar cane and has a microscopic morphology similar to that of species in the genus Nocardiopsis. It is so named because of the presence of beadlike chains of sheath-enclosed spores formed by segmentation of the aerial hyphae. The organism grows at temperatures between 25 and 50°C, with optimum growth at 37 to 40°C (27). There are approximately 40 described species and subspecies in the genus.

sect1.title: Segniliparus
sect1.para: The presence of unique high-pressure liquid chromato-graphy mycolic acid patterns in four clinical isolates thought to belong to the genusMycobacterium initiated an investigation into the characteristics of this recently described genus. By 16S rRNA gene sequencing, the genus is most closely related to members of the genus Rhodococcus, and cell wall chemistry places it in the suborder Corynebacterineae with Rhodococcus and other related genera (28). Segniliparus is the only aerobic actinomycete (besides Mycobacterium) that is strongly acid fast (Fig. 2M and Fig. 3M and 3N). There are two validly described species in this genus that are of clinical significance.

sect1.title: Streptomyces
sect1.para: The genus- and species-level taxonomy of this huge group, which contains over 950 named species and subspecies, remains problematic (29, 30). Many of these species have been patented because of the commercially useful products that they synthesize (29) (Fig. 2C).

sect1.title: Thermoactinomyces
sect1.para: The approximately 12 species of the genusThermoactinomyces are characterized by their production of abundant endospores that are resistant to heat and easily become airborne. Organisms are found in soil, moldy and decaying plant materials, and composts. By their 16S rRNA gene sequences and G+C contents, members of this genus are more closely related to the genus Bacillus than they are to the other genera considered aerobic actinomycetes, but they are considered with this group because of their similar morphologic features. Optimum growth temperatures vary by species, but most species grow between 35 and 58°C (31).

sect1.title: Tsukamurella
sect1.para: The genusTsukamurella was created to accommodate organisms with a specific cell wall chemistry that separated them from other aerobic actinomycetes (32). The type species of the genus, T. paurometabola, was previously known as Corynebacterium paurometabolum. There are approximately 22 named species in this genus (Fig. 2J and 2K and Fig. 3J).

sect1.title: Williamsia
sect1.para: The genusWilliamsia was established to include environmental organisms that resembled those in genera belonging to the family Nocardiaceae but that had unusual cell morphology. When examined by electron microscopy, cells of Williamsia show hairy structures distributed over the whole surface of the cell. These structures are not visible in negatively staining preparations, indicating that the structures are composed of fibrillar capsular material and not true fimbriae (33). The genus contains approximately 13 species (Fig. 2N and 2O and Fig. 3O).

sect2.title: EPIDEMIOLOGY AND TRANSMISSION
sect2.para: While the aerobic actinomycetes are widely distributed in the environment, including soil and aquatic habitats, the extent to which particular species are geographically restricted is not well known. Their primary ecological role is probably the decomposition of plant material. They are also potential pathogens of domestic livestock (30).

The majority of infections caused by aerobic actinomycetes stem from environmental sources. They are causative agents of mycetoma, cutaneous infections and abscesses, and pulmonary and occasionally disseminated disease. Actinomycetoma is a form of cutaneous disease caused by aerobic actinomycetes, specificallyActinomadura species, Streptomyces species, and Nocardia species. It is common in the “mycetoma belt” located around the Tropic of Cancer. Actinomycetomas caused by Nocardia species occur mostly in regions of higher humidity; actinomycetomas caused by other aerobic actinomycetes occur in drier regions (34).
Most health care-related infections appear to be attributable to an environmental source. Person-to-person transmission has not been documented.

Two outbreaks ofGordonia bronchialis sternal wound infections were traced to nurses from whose hands and other body sites the organism was isolated. In one case, the organism was also isolated from two of the nurses’ dogs (35, 36). Exmelin et al. reported an outbreak of N. farcinica among heart transplant patients as determined by randomly amplified polymorphic DNA analysis; a source of the outbreak was not determined (37). An outbreak of bloodstream infections attributed to Tsukamurella species among 15 patients with indwelling central lines was reported in a West Virginia oncology clinic. The only significant risk factor was the use of a saline flush prepared from a common-source bag of saline (38).

An outbreak of pseudo-infection attributed toT. paurometabola, involving specimens from 10 patients and attributed to a common laboratory source that contaminated the specimens, has been reported (39). Additional pseudo-outbreaks attributed to T. paurometabola and Tsukamurella tyrosinosolvens (due to improperly wrapped and subsequently contaminated specimen processing equipment) have been reported (39, 40).

sect2.title: CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
sect2.para: While the number of recognized species of aerobic actinomycetes is rapidly increasing, assessment of the clinical significance of many species is becoming increasingly difficult. In some cases, a new species is described on the basis of a single isolate, and while careful attention is paid to its molecular features, little or no information may be provided to document that the isolate was actually a cause of disease in the patient from whom it was isolated. While gene sequencing is now frequently used for the identification of aerobic actinomycetes implicated as the cause of human disease, in many older reports of the isolation of a specific organism, the accuracy of the reported identifications may be in doubt because of the provision of inadequate detail regarding the molecular technique used and the methods of result interpretation employed. Furthermore, many identifications reported in the older literature would be considered incorrect by currently accepted species criteria; perhaps the best example is that ofN. asteroides, which has only rarely been documented to be a human pathogen using currently accepted taxonomy.

Unfortunately, all these factors hinder the accurate association of clinically useful information with a given species, especially among less frequently encountered species and genera. There is a tendency to assemble species into “groups” on the basis of certain features, such as antimicrobial susceptibility, as was originally done by Wallace et al. for what were considered antibiogram types ofN. asteroides; these groups are now divided into different species (41).

Table 2 lists species of aerobic actinomycetes other than those in the genus Nocardia that have been described as human pathogens and identified using gene sequence analysis. The table indicates the specimen sources from which the organisms were isolated and further notes on whether the isolated organism was clinically significant. Table 3 lists species of Nocardia that have been reported to be isolated from humans. Whenever a laboratory isolates an aerobic actinomycete whose sequence indicates that the organism belongs to a species that has rarely been isolated, the circumstances surrounding the isolation of the organism should be carefully evaluated to assess its potential clinical significance (see Tables 2 and 3). A search of the current literature may be conducted to determine what is already established regarding that species, including its known pathogenicity and antibiotic susceptibilities. For such searches, the LPSN and PubMed (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/) databases may be good starting points; current nomenclature and taxonomic standing should be followed as stated in the LPSN.

For the genera listed below, every attempt was made to include only information for which identifications were determined using gene sequencing.Tables 2 and 3 provide summaries of the types of infections caused by clinically significant aerobic actinomycetes (non-nocardial) and Nocardia species, respectively.

sect1.title: Actinomadura
sect1.para: A useful clue to the identification of organisms in the genusActinomadura is the nature of the lesion from which an isolate originates. Usually, this organism causes a mycetoma, a chronic, invasive, slowly progressive infection usually occurring in the foot (Madura foot) and nearby anatomic structures and nearly always resulting from traumatic implantation of the organism. Draining sinuses are typically present in a mycetoma; macroscopically visible grains (organism aggregates or microcolonies) may be visible in the discharge from the lesions. The infection occurs most frequently in tropical regions, where people are more likely to walk barefoot. The word “mycetoma” is used only to describe the clinical nature of the infection, not the etiologic agent. Actinomycotic mycetomas are caused by aerobic actinomycetes; eumycotic mycetomas are caused by true fungi. Organisms in the genus Actinomadura have rarely been implicated in other types of infection; infections of the tongue and spine and abdominal wall have been reported (42, 43) (see Table 2). Actinomadura madurae and Actinomadura pelletieri have been the two species most frequently reported as pathogens; recently, a new species, Actinomadura sputi, was isolated from a patient with a respiratory infection (44). In many older reports mentioning the species causing mycetomas, identification has been made solely on the basis of the histological appearance of the grains, on the basis of a small number of phenotypic tests, or in ways not specified in any detail. As with virtually all the aerobic actinomycetes, molecular methods are the only procedures that allow definitive species-level identification of organisms in this genus.

sect1.title: Amycolatopsis
sect1.para: The only recent report of the isolation of anAmycolatopsis species from a human source describes the new species Amycolatopsis palatopharyngis from the palatopharyngeal mucosa of an elderly patient. The report provides no information regarding the pathogenicity of this isolate (45).

sect1.title: Dermatophilus
sect1.para: D. congolensis causes dermatitis in a wide variety of animals worldwide, including cattle, horses, goats, and sheep, but has only rarely been noted as a cause of human infection (46). In humans, the organism has been reported to cause a variety of cutaneous manifestations, including pruritic skin rash, scaling and exudative lesions, pustules, pitted keratolysis, and hairy leukoplakia of the tongue. Filamentous and coccoid forms of the organism may be visualized directly in tissue specimens. Optimal therapy has not been defined, but infections may be self-limiting. This organism should be considered in travelers returning from tropical areas, particularly if lesions develop subsequent to animal contact at a site of previous skin trauma (46).

sect1.title: Dietzia
sect1.para: Until recently, the few reported cases of infection attributed toDietzia species have been attributed to D. maris; these include isolates from blood and an intravascular catheter (47), from an infection associated with a hip prosthesis (48), and from a case of aortic dissection (49). Recent reports have described the isolation of additional Dietzia species from clinical specimens including Dietzia aurantiaca (50), Dietzia cinnamea (51), and Dietzia papillomatosis (52). In some of these cases the clinical significance of the isolate was not clear. The recent description of these new species is a result of the use of protein analysis and gene sequencing to assist in the definitive identification of isolates of this genus. Traditional biochemical testing or the use of commercially available Gram-positive rod identification panels may not adequately distinguish between Dietzia species and R. equi (53). One report also notes the impossibility of distinguishing between certain pairs of Dietzia species (e.g., D. maris and D. schimae), even with the use of gene sequencing of two different molecular targets (53). It is not clear whether any currently available method can distinguish between these two species.

sect1.title: Gordonia
sect1.para: Recent reports suggest an increasing frequency of isolation ofGordonia species; these reports also list an increasing number of species implicated in human infection. However, an unknown number of Gordonia infections may be missed, either because the isolate is considered an insignificant coryneform Gram-positive rod or because the isolate is misidentified by biochemical methods as belonging to another genus, such as Nocardia or Rhodococcus (54). The range of infections caused by Gordonia species includes primary bacteremia and respiratory, cutaneous, and central nervous system infections (see Table 2). Numerous reported infections have been shown to be catheter-, dialysis-, and implanted medical device-related (55–57). Rarely, clusters of infection have involved patients who developed sternal-wound infections following cardiac surgery (36, 58). As with other members of the aerobic actinomycetes, immunocompromised status appears to be a contributing factor in many of the infections caused by Gordonia species (59).

sect1.title: Kroppenstedtia
sect1.para: Fourteen clinical isolates ofK. eburnea have been reported, mostly from blood (60) or other sterile fluids, and one from skin. It is not clear that any of the isolates were of clinical significance. However, because most isolates were recovered from sterile fluids, this genus is included here, pending future determination of its true clinical significance.

The isolates were identified by partial 16S rRNA sequencing and MALDI-TOF MS. Of the 11 isolates available for antimicrobial susceptibility testing, all were susceptible to most agents tested but resistant to clarithromycin. The authors of that report noted that the organisms were not acid fast and did not stain with auramine O. The report made no mention of the presence of an aerial mycelium (60).

sect1.title: Lawsonella
sect1.para: The single species included in the genusLawsonella, L. clevelandensis, has been isolated from spinal, peritoneal, breast, and liver abscesses in immunocompromised patients. All but one of the patients had type 2 diabetes mellitus. Because the organism is fastidious (requiring less than 1% oxygen tension and 5 to 7 days until visible growth appears), its presence as an opportunistic pathogen could easily be overlooked (13).

sect1.title: Nocardia
sect1.para: Nocardia infections generally result either from trauma-related introduction of the organism or, particularly in immunocompromised patients, from inhalation and the resulting establishment of a pulmonary focus. Nocardia species have also been implicated in extrapulmonary disease in a variety of body sites; this usually results from hematogenous spread from a pulmonary focus. The brain is one of the most common secondary sites of infection (61). Various Nocardia species have also been implicated as the causal agents of keratitis and other ocular infections, but the accuracy of the species-level identification in these reports is not always clear (62). In addition, a few cases of catheter-related Nocardia infections have been reported, but the precise species involved has not always been unambiguously identified (63). A well-documented case of catheter-related infection caused by N. farcinica has been recently reported (64).

In 1988 a breakthrough in the clinically useful categorization of pathogenicNocardia isolates was provided by Wallace and his coworkers (41). They divided organisms phenotypically resembling N. asteroides into six drug pattern types and one additional miscellaneous group. With more recent molecular characterizations, numerous species have been described within this set of organisms, which came to be known as the N. asteroides complex. These include Nocardia abscessus (drug pattern I), Nocardia nova (drug pattern III), Nocardia wallacei (drug pattern IV), Nocardia farcinica (drug pattern V), Nocardia cyriacigeorgica (drug pattern VI), and other isolates comprising drug pattern II. Other new Nocardia species are continually being described, and undoubtedly, by current species definition criteria, many more will be described in the future.

Given the current state of the literature, it is possible to make only the most tentative statements regarding geographic distribution and disease correlates of different species. While accurate species assignment allows one to make some predictions regarding likely antimicrobial susceptibility patterns, such a species assignment today requires the use of molecular methods (61). Of the more than 100 species of Nocardia currently recognized, almost one-half have been reported as human isolates, and several others have been reported as pathogens of animals. Importantly, isolates in many reports of infection, even in the recent literature, are incorrectly identified because of failure to use optimal identification methods.

sect2.title: Nocardia abscessus
sect2.para: N. abscessus was formally named in 2000 by Yassin et al. (65). ATCC strain 23824, the reference strain of N. asteroides drug pattern type I (66), was one of the isolates found to be N. abscessus on the basis of 16S rRNA sequencing and DNA-DNA hybridization. In their description in 1988 of the antimicrobial susceptibility patterns of 78 clinical isolates of Nocardia from various sources, Wallace et al. noted that 20% of the isolates had this drug pattern type (41). Several of the strains in the report naming the species were from abscesses; a subsequent report from Japan reported several isolates from pulmonary sources and one from a brain abscess (67). Two isolates have been reported from Germany, one from pericardial fluid (68) and the other from a posttraumatic wound (69). More recent cases have included a report of disseminated infection in an AIDS patient (70).
SeeTable 4 for the expected antimicrobial susceptibility pattern of N. abscessus.

sect2.title: Nocardia amikacinitolerans
sect2.para: Five clinical isolates including two from ocular sources were identified using 16S rRNA andgyrB sequences. DNA-DNA hybridization showed the isolates to be a new species. The most noteworthy characteristic of the isolates was its specific resistance to amikacin. Until the designation of this species in 2013, the only known amikacin-resistant group of Nocardia was the N. transvalensis complex, which is resistant to all aminoglycosides (71). Since isolation of this new species, several other clinical cases of N. amikacinitolerans, including brain abscess, have been described (72).

sect2.title: Nocardia asteroides and the “N. asteroides Complex”
sect2.para: There are innumerable reports of human infection attributed toN. asteroides; it has probably been considered the most commonly isolated human-pathogenic Nocardia species. However, the molecular analyses of the pathogenic isolates attributed to this species that have been conducted so far have indicated that all belong to some other named or as-yet-unnamed species. It is currently believed that N. asteroides sensu stricto is rarely recovered in clinical laboratories and is rarely pathogenic (73).

The term “N. asteroides complex” has been used for organisms phenotypically resembling the N. asteroides type strain. However, several distinct species have now been described within that complex, and precisely what the complex is intended to designate is usually unclear. Given the current ability to identify Nocardia isolates by molecular methods, the phrase “N. asteroides complex” should be avoided. The term “complex” is best restricted to groups of species that are related on a molecular basis and have similar phenotypic features. Such groups include the N. nova complex and the Nocardia transvalensis complex. Whenever the term “complex” is used, it is best to state initially precisely which species are intended to be included in the complex.

sect2.title: Nocardia brasiliensis
sect2.para: N. brasiliensis appears to be the most common cause of actinomycotic mycetoma (see “Actinomadura” above) in the Western Hemisphere, especially in Mexico (74). The organism probably occurs worldwide; there are reports of infection from Australia (75), West Bengal (76), and Europe (77) and many reports from North America (78). A variety of cutaneous manifestations in addition to mycetoma, including cellulitis, abscesses, and lymphocutaneous infection, have been reported. Nearly all cases are a result of trauma, including those caused by thorns (77), cat scratch (79), and insect bite (80). Most of the trauma-related infections have occurred in immunocompetent individuals. Disseminated infection, usually originating from a pulmonary focus, has also been reported (78); such infections are more likely to occur in immunocompromised patients (81). Some cases, such as one of a brain abscess resulting from dissemination from a pulmonary focus (82), occur in patients who appear to be immunocompetent. However, most of the cases of invasive disease, as well as some of the cases of cutaneous infection, attributed to N. brasiliensis (prior to 1995) almost certainly have been caused by Nocardia pseudobrasiliensis (see below).
SeeTable 4 for the expected antimicrobial susceptibility pattern of N. brasiliensis.

sect2.title: Nocardia brevicatena/Nocardia paucivorans
sect2.para: Brown et al. suggested in 1997 thatNocardia isolates sharing both an unusual drug susceptibility pattern and one or another of three restriction fragment length polymorphism patterns of an amplified portion of the 65-kDa heat shock protein (HSP) gene should be considered to form the N. brevicatena complex (83). These organisms included 19 clinical isolates from the United States, 10 clinical isolates from Australia, and 3 ATCC reference strains of N. brevicatena. There have been no subsequent reports of clinical isolates or taxonomic studies of these organisms.

The speciesN. paucivorans was described by Yassin et al. in 2000 on the basis of a respiratory isolate from a patient with chronic lung disease (84). By 16S rRNA gene sequencing, this organism showed 99.6% sequence similarity to N. brevicatena; results of DNA-DNA hybridization indicated that they were distinct species. N. paucivorans and N. brevicatena, along with isolates belonging to the unnamed group N. asteroides drug pattern II (41), are sometimes considered to belong to the N. paucivorans/N. brevicatena complex based on similar phenotypic characteristics and antibiograms (61). Attempting species-level discrimination among isolates in the N. paucivorans/N. brevicatena complex is currently beyond the capability of most clinical laboratories.

N. paucivorans has been recovered from cerebrospinal fluid in a case of cerebral nocardiosis in an immunocompromised individual (85), an intracerebral abscess in an immunocompetent patient (86), and a mitral valve (87). Two of 86 (2.3%) clinical Nocardia isolates from Belgium were identified as belonging to this species (88).

sect2.title: Nocardia cyriacigeorgica
sect2.para: N. cyriacigeorgica was described on the basis of an isolate obtained from the sputum of a patient with chronic bronchitis (89). Subsequent isolates were obtained from brain abscesses in an immunocompromised patient (90) and from a patient with pneumonia following a near-drowning incident, from whom N. farcinica and several other pathogens were also isolated (91). Isolates of this species were reported to constitute 13 of 96 (14%) clinical Nocardia isolates from Thailand (92) and 13 of 86 (15%) such isolates from Belgium (88). The 16S rRNA sequence of the type strain of this species (1,400 bp) was found to be identical to that of the reference strain of N. asteroides drug pattern type VI (ATCC 14759) (66, 93). DNA-DNA hybridization studies subsequently established that this drug pattern type VI reference strain and N. cyriacigeorgica belong to the same species (94). In the original work describing the different N. asteroides drug pattern types, type VI strains were the most commonly isolated strains (35%) (41). N. cyriacigeorgica is probably the most frequent human nocardial pathogen, at least in areas where actinomycotic mycetomas are relatively rare. While the species N. cyriacigeorgica has been designated an emerging pathogen (95), it is actually a relatively common and long-recognized pathogen that has recently acquired a valid name. In fact, many isolates previously reported as N. asteroides almost certainly belong to this species.

sect2.title: Nocardia farcinica/Nocardia kroppenstedtii
sect2.para: The organisms initially described by Wallace et al. as belonging to the groupN. asteroides drug pattern type V (41) were subsequently found to belong to N. farcinica (96). N. farcinica isolates that showed in vitro resistance to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole have been reported to respond to meropenem alone (97) and to the combination of linezolid and minocycline (98). This species may have a particular propensity for causing disseminated disease; Wallace et al. reported that among 30 patients for which the disease extent was known, 57% had disseminated disease and one-third had central nervous system involvement (96). Most patients infected by this species, especially those with disseminated disease, have some type of immunocompromising state (96), but cutaneous and other infections have been reported to occur in the apparently immunocompetent as well (99). The lung is a common site of involvement, affecting 59.7% of patients according to one review (99). As verified by molecular analysis, N. farcinica has been isolated from brain abscesses (100), blood (100), cases of keratitis (101), and an infected cochlear implant (102). N. farcinica has been implicated as a cause of pneumonia in a cystic fibrosis patient (103). Isolates of this species were reported to make up 34 of 96 (35%) clinical Nocardia isolates from Thailand (92) and 38 of 86 (44%) such isolates from Belgium (88).

A recent multicenter European study ofNocardia infections in solid-organ transplant recipients found that N. farcinica was more frequently associated with brain, skin, and subcutaneous tissue infections than other species of Nocardia (104).

The recently described speciesNocardia kroppenstedtii is nearly indistinguishable from N. farcinica and shares a 16S rRNA gene sequence similarity of 99.8%, with only three nucleotide differences (105). DNA-DNA relatedness of N. kroppenstedtii and the N. farcinica type strain was evaluated using a proposed method that measures thermal denaturation temperatures (106), and results indicated that N. farcinica and N. kroppenstedtii are two separate species. However, based on the similarity of the 16S rRNA gene sequences of these two species and the use of a proposed method of assessing DNA-DNA relatedness, the determination of whether or not N. kroppenstedtii is indeed a species distinct from N. farcinica will require further study.
SeeTable 4 for the expected antimicrobial susceptibility pattern of N. farcinica.

sect2.title: Nocardia nova
sect2.para: N. nova was described by Tsukamura in 1982, distinguished from N. asteroides by several phenotypic tests (107), and confirmed to be a separate and distinct species by DNA-DNA hybridization (108). Wallace et al. found that 18% of 78 clinical isolates fell into their type III drug susceptibility pattern, characterized by susceptibility to ampicillin and erythromycin and resistance to carbenicillin (41). In a subsequent study of 223 clinical isolates, by both biochemical and susceptibility testing procedures, 17% of the isolates, as well as the type strain of N. nova, had similar characteristics, including the type III drug pattern; these isolates were all then considered N. nova strains (109). Of the patients for whom clinical information was available, 35% were thought to have disseminated disease; organisms were obtained from many sites, including blood, lung, central nervous system, skin and soft tissue, joints, and cornea. An upper extremity sporotrichoid form of nocardiosis attributed to N. nova in a human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-positive patient who sustained a thumb injury while working in a field has been reported (110). Hamdad et al. reported the isolation of N. nova, identified by 16S rRNA gene sequencing, from a case of spondylodiscitis and psoas abscess (111).

Investigations have revealed that the organisms identified asN. nova by phenotypic testing, including antibiogram pattern, as well as by the restriction fragment length polymorphism patterns obtainable from the hsp65 gene, actually belong to other species in addition to N. nova, including Nocardia africana, Nocardia kruczakiae, and Nocardia veterana (112). These species can be distinguished from one another and from N. nova sensu stricto only by gene sequencing. Similarity analysis using sequence data of the HSP and secA1 genes consistently places these species in the same group as N. nova sensu stricto, indicating the considerable genetic similarity among these species (113). Similarity analysis of the 16S rRNA, HSP, and secA1 genes also groups Nocardia aobensis and Nocardia elegans with the N. nova complex; no phenotypic characteristics of these two species have been examined to determine their similarity to other species in the complex. All species included in the N. nova complex (including N. aobensis and N. elegans) have been isolated from humans or implicated in human disease. Isolates identified only by phenotypic testing as belonging to one or another of these species are probably best reported as members of the N. nova complex.
SeeTable 4 for the expected antimicrobial susceptibility pattern of members of the N. nova complex.

sect2.title: Nocardia otitidiscaviarum
sect2.para: The initial isolate ofN. otitidiscaviarum, described by Snijders in 1924, was obtained from the infected middle ear of a guinea pig; for a time this species was known as Nocardia caviae (114). Clark et al. reviewed 28 cases of cutaneous infection, including several mycetoma cases, attributed to this species; many of those for which information was available were considered trauma related (115). There are a few reports of infection at other sites, including a brain abscess (116), a pyothorax infection (117), a catheter-related infection (118), disseminated infection (119), and cavitary pneumonia (120). In a molecular study of numerous clinical isolates, several sequences were obtained from nine strains that had been phenotypically identified as N. otitidiscaviarum (121). These results were interpreted as suggesting the presence of several species within this group, but some of the results also suggested that individual isolates might contain two or more differing copies of the 16S rRNA gene.
SeeTable 4 for the expected antimicrobial susceptibility pattern of N. otitidiscaviarum.

sect2.title: Nocardia pseudobrasiliensis
sect2.para: In 1995, Wallace et al. (122) reported on a subset of organisms that had been identified as N. brasiliensis that were sometimes isolated from cutaneous infections but were predominantly associated with noncutaneous invasive disease. This subset of isolates appeared to belong to another taxon, formally named N. pseudobrasiliensis the following year (123). Most infections have occurred in immunocompromised patients; cases have been reported from North and South America, Japan, and Australia (122, 124, 125).

Unlike trueN. brasiliensis isolates, most N. pseudobrasiliensis isolates hydrolyze adenine, are susceptible to ciprofloxacin and clarithromycin, and are resistant to minocycline. The two species also differ in their mycolic acid patterns and 16S rRNA, HSP, and secA1 gene sequences. Most cases of infectious disease of a nonmycetomatous nature previously attributed to N. brasiliensis have probably been caused by this species (see “Nocardia brasiliensis” above).
SeeTable 4 for the expected antimicrobial susceptibility pattern of N. pseudobrasiliensis.

sect2.title: Nocardia transvalensis and the N. transvalensis Complex
sect2.para: N. transvalensis was originally described in 1927 on the basis of an isolate from an African patient with a mycetoma (126). In 1997, Wilson et al. published a study of 58 clinical isolates from the United States and Australia that showed resistance to all aminoglycosides, including amikacin, which was characteristic of this complex (127). Using biochemical and molecular methods, these authors were able to separate the isolates into four distinct groups. One group comprised 53% of the isolates studied, were all recovered from patients in the United States, and were similar to isolates classified as N. asteroides drug pattern type IV as defined by Wallace et al. (41). Isolates belonging to this group were later officially designated N. wallacei (128) (see below). A second group (17% of isolates) included organisms similar to the type strain of N. transvalensis. Two additional groups, new taxon 1 (14% of isolates) and new taxon 2 (16% of isolates), were also defined. Australian isolates belonged either to the N. transvalensis sensu stricto group or to new taxon 1. Isolates belonging to new taxon 1 have been given the species designation Nocardia blacklockiae (128). Because of their similar phenotypic and molecular characteristics, Wilson proposed that these three species (N. blacklockiae, N. transvalensis, and N. wallacei) and the unnamed new taxon 2 be considered to belong to the N. transvalensis complex. Gene sequencing distinguishes these species from each other and from the newly described species N. amikacinitolerans, which is also uniformly resistant to amikacin (71).

There have been numerous reports in the literature describing the isolation ofN. transvalensis from clinical specimens; many of these reports base the identification of the isolate on a small number of phenotypic tests. It is doubtful that most of these reports represent accurate species assignments, given the similarity of related species as described above. McNeil et al. reported on 16 patients from whom isolates attributed to this species had been obtained (129). The isolates from 10 of the patients were considered clinically significant; the other isolates were considered colonizers or of uncertain significance. A variety of sites of infection were involved, some of the infections were disseminated, and several patients were known to be immunocompromised. There are a few other case reports of disseminated infection attributed to the N. transvalensis complex identified using molecular methods, including a brain abscess in a cancer patient (130), brain and cutaneous infection in a heart transplant patient (131), and pulmonary infection and subcutaneous abscess in a patient with histiocytosis X (132). Three clinical isolates assigned to this species complex have been reported from Japan (133). A well-documented case of N. transvalensis has also been reported in a case of pneumonia in a patient with cystic fibrosis (134).

Those using 16S rRNA gene sequencing for identification of members of theN. transvalensis complex should be aware that numerous sequences for N. transvalensis have been submitted to GenBank. Many of these sequences are more closely related to the type strain of N. wallacei than to the type strain of N. transvalensis.
SeeTable 4 for the expected antimicrobial susceptibility pattern of members of the N. transvalensis complex.

sect2.title: Nocardia veterana
sect2.para: N. veterana was first described on the basis of an isolate obtained from the bronchial lavage fluid of a patient with pulmonary lesions, but that isolate was thought not to be clinically significant (135). Subsequently, N. veterana has been implicated as the causative agent in cases of mycetomas (136), three patients with pulmonary disease (137), ascitic fluid infection in an HIV patient (138), brain abscess in a diabetic patient (139), and bloodstream infection in a cancer patient (140). In a report of three additional clinical isolates, two of which were shown to have been causative agents of pulmonary disease, it was noted that the isolates had an antimicrobial susceptibility pattern essentially identical to the patterns of N. africana and N. nova (141), demonstrating that species identification could not be definitively established by susceptibility testing alone. It was also noted that the isolates of this species that were studied showed 16S rRNA gene similarities to the type strains of N. africana and N. nova of 99.0 and 97.7%, respectively. N. veterana is one of the species included in the N. nova complex (see “Nocardia nova” above). HSP, secA1, and 16S rRNA gene sequencing place N. veterana in a group with other members of the complex. The expected antimicrobial susceptibility pattern of N. veterana is consistent with the susceptibility pattern of members of the N. nova complex (see above).

sect2.title: Nocardia wallacei
sect2.para: Officially described in 2008,N. wallacei is the most commonly isolated member of the N. transvalensis complex (128). 16S rRNA, HSP, and secA1 gene sequencing showed ≥99.8% sequence similarity among five clinical isolates obtained from sputum samples; one of these was also recovered from pleural fluid. This species was initially designated N. asteroides drug pattern IV by Wallace et al. and comprised 5% of 78 isolates identified as N. asteroides by phenotypic methods but unique in their resistance to amikacin (41). The expected antimicrobial susceptibility pattern of N. wallacei is consistent with the susceptibility pattern of members of the N. transvalensis complex (see above).

sect1.title: Nocardiopsis
sect1.para: Nearly all of the very few infections attributed to organisms in the genusNocardiopsis have been attributed to Nocardiopsis dassonvillei. N. dassonvillei has been isolated from blood, mycetomas, cutaneous infections caused by trauma, and a nasal vestibulitis abscess (142–144).

sect1.title: Rhodococcus
sect1.para: The most commonly isolated pathogen in the genusRhodococcus is R. equi; there have been recent reports of the isolation of Rhodococcus corynebacterioides (145) and Rhodococcus faciens (146) from blood and liver lesions, respectively. There is some evidence that R. equi itself may be a complex of several species (147). The organism has long been known as a significant pulmonary pathogen in horses (hence the species name) (148). The initial report of human disease caused by the organism (reported as Corynebacterium equi) involved a patient on high-dose steroids with a pulmonary abscess; he had worked briefly in stockyards contaminated with animal feces shortly before the onset of his illness (149). Herbivore manure provides an ideal growth medium for the organism, and inhalation of the organism is presumed to be the major mode of infection in horses (148) and is probably also the principal mechanism for human infections. Direct inoculation and oral ingestion are other possible routes of infection (150). Most patients who develop R. equi infection are immunocompromised, and at least until recently, approximately two-thirds of infected patients were also HIV infected (150).

Essentially any body site can be involved, but the lung is the primary site of involvement in approximately 80% of immunocompromised patients and at least 40% of immunocompetent patients. Bacteremia has been reported in >80% of immunocompromised patients and approximately 30% of immunocompetent patients (150). Pulmonary cavitation is a frequent finding. Mulè et al. describe five patients, some of whom were immunocompetent, who presented with malacoplakia (an aggregation of histiocytes containing concentrically layered basophilic structures known as Michaelis-Gutmann bodies, which simulate malignancy) from which R. equi was isolated (151). Two virulence-associated antigens (VapA and VapB) encoded by plasmids have been identified. Isolates producing the VapA antigen are the predominant, possibly the sole, cause of disease in horses, but isolates producing the VapA antigen, the VapB antigen, or neither antigen have been isolated from human cases of infection (152). Without careful assessment, R. equi isolates can easily be mistaken for coryneform bacteria and dismissed as insignificant (Fig. 2H). One report describes two patients who died of overwhelming R. equi infection; for both patients, isolates from multiple positive blood cultures were initially misidentified as a Corynebacterium species (153). Infections caused by R. equi may also be misdiagnosed in areas of high prevalence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (154).

Recently, multidrug resistance has been seen following antibiotic prophylaxis (with macrolides and rifampin) of equine farms in the U.S. due to a clone,R. equi 2287 of pRErm46 with chromosomal rpoβ. This clone is currently being reported in the U.S. and could easily spread internationally through horse carriers. Moreover, a major concern is the risk of zoonotic transmission to other pathogens either directly or through the environment (155).

sect1.title: Segniliparus
sect1.para: Although the two species that make up this genus (Segniliparus rotundus and Segniliparus rugosus) were originally recovered from clinical material, no information was provided concerning the significance of these isolates except that they were from “nonsterile human sources” (28). Isolates of these species have been isolated from respiratory specimens and show microscopic and colonial similarities with Tsukamurella species and with rapidly growing mycobacteria (28) (Fig. 2M and Fig. 3M and 3N). Reports of the recovery of S. rugosus seem to indicate the predilection of this organism for patients with cystic fibrosis. However, a recent report describes the isolation of S. rugosus from an immunocompetent non-cystic fibrosis patient (156). In another report from Australia, S. rugosus was isolated from the mycobacterial culture of sputum from a cystic fibrosis patient (157). A case of S. rotundus pneumonia in a non-cystic fibrosis patient with bronchiectasis has recently been reported (158).

sect1.title: Streptomyces
sect1.para: The most common type of infection attributed to species in the genusStreptomyces is actinomycetoma (see “Actinomadura” above), and the most commonly mentioned etiologic agent is Streptomyces somaliensis, although in many reports the identification procedures employed could not have unambiguously identified the isolate. One recent report identified Streptomyces albus as the cause of actinomycetoma as determined by 16S rRNA sequencing (159). There are a few reports implicating other species in the genus as occasional pathogens. In case reports of bacteremias attributed to Streptomyces bikiniensis (catheter-related) (160) and Streptomyces thermovulgaris (161), isolates were identified by 16S rRNA gene sequences. While the majority of isolates from nonmycetomatous lesions probably represent either contamination or colonization, these organisms are capable of occasionally causing disease other than mycetoma, including keratitis (162) and pneumonia (163). Because of the huge number of validly described species of Streptomyces and the lack of information about the clinical significance of many of these species, identification to the genus level is probably sufficient in most cases.

sect1.title: Tsukamurella
sect1.para: Infections caused byTsukamurella species may be attributed to other organisms (such as rapidly growing mycobacteria, Corynebacterium species, or Rhodococcus species) if molecular identification methods are not employed. Bloodstream infections caused by Tsukamurella species have been most commonly reported in connection with intravenous catheters (164) but have also been reported even in apparently immunologically normal patients in the absence of any foreign body (165). Eye infections are frequently caused by a variety of Tsukamurella species (T. tyrosinosolvens, T. spumae, T. pulmonis, T. honkongensis) (166, 167). T. tyrosinosolvens has been implicated in cases of keratitis, bacteremia, and catheter-related infections. Bloodstream infections have been attributed to Tsukamurella strandjordae (168) and T. pulmonis (169).

sect1.title: Williamsia
sect1.para: The first clinical isolate of the genusWilliamsia was recovered from a protected bronchial brush sample of a patient with bilateral alveolar infiltrates following aortic valve replacement. A Gram stain of the sample showed numerous Gram-positive rods, and culture of the fluid grew >1,000 CFU/ml of an organism identified by 16S rRNA gene sequencing as Williamsia muralis (99.9% sequence similarity) (170). Two isolates of Williamsia deligens have been reported from human blood, but no clinical information was provided (171). A recent report describes the isolation of an additional species, Williamsia serinedens, from the blood of a pregnant woman (172).

sect1.title: Other Genera
sect1.para: Some other genera of aerobic actinomycetes have roles in human diseases but are unlikely to be encountered in the clinical laboratory. Organisms in three genera of thermophilic aerobic actinomycetes,Saccharomonospora, Saccharopolyspora, and Thermoactinomyces, have been implicated in the etiology of hypersensitivity pneumonitis. Spores of these organisms may be encountered when performing air sampling; molecular methods are helpful for species-level identification when needed (173, 174). A recently described sputum isolate has been placed in a new genus and species, Desmospora activa, in the family Thermoactinomycetaceae, but its pathogenic significance is unclear from the report (8).

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
sect2.para: In temperate climates, the respiratory tract is the most frequent portal of entry for the aerobic actinomycetes and therefore the primary site of nocardial infections in immunocompromised hosts. Sputum is the most easily obtained pulmonary specimen, and examination of several fresh early-morning samples collected on separate days (175) may maximize the chances of organism recovery; isolation of an aerobic actinomycete from multiple samples may help to establish the clinical significance of the isolated organism (176). Nocardia species and other aerobic actinomycetes may, however, be difficult to recover from sputum even in documented cases of pulmonary infection (15), either because of low numbers of organisms present in the sample or because they may be overgrown by more rapidly growing bacteria in the specimen. More invasive procedures, such as bronchoalveolar lavage or fine-needle or open lung biopsy, may be required to obtain a definitive diagnosis (15). These more invasive procedures may be necessary for diagnosis of as many as 44% of primary pulmonary infections (75); macrophage-rich samples may be necessary to maximize recovery of organisms such as rhodococci, which tend to localize within these cells (21).

Exudates from abscesses or mycetomas should be delivered to the laboratory in a sterile container for macroscopic and microscopic examination for characteristic granules and for smear tests and culture. In the case of disseminated cutaneous lesions or small lesions secondary to trauma, a skin biopsy can be useful. The use of swabs is not recommended, because fibers can make smear interpretation difficult (175).

In immunocompromised patients, the aerobic actinomycetes, especiallyNocardia, can disseminate to almost any organ. A biopsy sample or aspirate, when obtainable, may be the best specimen to evaluate for the presence of such organisms. Normally sterile body fluids should be collected in a sterile container and sent immediately to the laboratory. Nocardia isolates are infrequently recovered from cerebrospinal fluid, even if numerous brain lesions are present, because the organisms may be confined to the brain abscess itself. Blood should be inoculated directly into blood culture media; many commercially available blood culture systems have been shown to support the growth of Nocardia species. Nocardia, Gordonia, and Tsukamurella species have been implicated as causes of catheter-related bacteremia; it is likely that other aerobic actinomycetes are also involved in catheter-related infections. Potentially infected catheter tips should be transported to the laboratory in a sterile container and cultured by appropriate methods.

In all cases where infection with an aerobic actinomycete is suspected, it is of the utmost importance that the laboratory be notified of the suspected diagnosis. This will ensure that samples will receive appropriate handling, that the correct direct smears will be prepared, and that the sample will be inoculated onto the appropriate media and incubated for an extended period of time (a minimum of 2 weeks, preferably for up to 3 weeks) at the appropriate temperature (177).
All samples should be transported promptly to the laboratory following the specimen collection and handling procedures outlined inchapter 19 of this Manual.

sect1.title: Microscopy
sect1.para: Careful microscopic examination of clinical specimens suspected of containing aerobic actinomycetes is extremely important. The observation of organisms characteristic ofNocardia species and other aerobic actinomycetes should alert laboratory personnel to inoculate appropriate media and to extend incubation at the appropriate temperature. In addition, the detection of organisms directly in the specimen may assist in the interpretation of culture results; smears of such specimens may show more characteristic diagnostic morphologies of organisms than smears from colonial growth.

Smears can be made directly from sputum, drainages, and aspirates; however, liquid specimens, such as bronchoalveolar lavage fluid or normally sterile body fluids that are not excessively cellular, should be concentrated before smear preparation and medium inoculation. For example, a 5-ml aliquot of the sample can be centrifuged for 10 min at 2,800 ×g, and the pellet can be used for smears and medium inoculation. Alternatively, smears can be prepared using a cytocentrifuge. For tissue samples, smears should be made from ground material and from touch preps. Two important stains that should be used in clinical laboratories for direct samples are the Gram stain and the modified acid-fast stain. Histopathologic examination of fixed tissue by use of special stains (including Fite stain and Grocott-Gomori methenamine silver stain) may also reveal the presence of organisms belonging to these genera (178).

Gram stain morphologies of the aerobic actinomycetes vary by genus; organisms appear as Gram-positive rods ranging in shape from coccoid to bacillary. Filamentous and branching forms may be present, depending on the species involved and the stage of growth in infected tissues (Fig. 3). See Table 1 for a summary of the microscopic morphologies of the aerobic actinomycetes.

A carefully interpreted modified acid-fast stain from direct specimens may more accurately reflect the true partially acid-fast nature of the organisms than do modified acid-fast stains prepared from colonial growth, possibly due to the effects from artificial media, variations in the type of media on which the organism was grown, and the age of the culture (30). The modified acid-fast stain uses a weaker decolorizer (1% H2SO4) than does the mycobacterial stain (3% HCl). The decolorization step of the staining process should be carefully monitored to reduce the risk of over- or underdecolorization. Because of the difficulty of standardizing the modified acid-fast staining technique, it is imperative that positive and negative controls be run simultaneously with patient smears. The control slides can be made from growing suspensions of Streptomyces species (negative control) and Nocardia species (positive control). Smears should be evaluated by experienced laboratory personnel, and the quality of the stain itself should be evaluated before results are reported. Gordonia, Nocardia, Rhodococcus, and Tsukamurella (and possibly Dietzia) are known to be partially acid fast with this stain; Segniliparus is strongly acid fast.

When smears are read, careful attention should be paid to the cellular material present in the sample (Fig. 3K and L). Nocardia species are frequently seen in association with polymorphonuclear leukocytes (61). Phagocytized Gram-positive or modified-acid-fast-stain-positive organisms can sometimes be seen within macrophages and mononuclear cells; in the modified acid-fast smear, these may appear as “beaded” cells with strongly acid-fast granules within non-acid-fast or weakly acid-fast rods (14, 21).

In cases of suspected actinomycetoma, aspirated material should be examined grossly for the presence of granules by spreading the sample in a sterile petri dish. Granules in infections caused byNocardia species are small (80 to 130 μm), may be kidney-shaped with clublike structures in the periphery, and are usually yellow to orange in color (179, 180). However, in a recent report of actinomycetoma caused by N. brasiliensis, giant white grains were discharged, possibly related to a specific subgroup of the infecting organism (181). In infections caused by A. madurae, granules can be yellowish white and large enough to be seen with the naked eye. Microscopically, a zone of pseudoclubs can be seen in the periphery (179). Granules in infections caused by A. pelletieri are red to pink in color (179). Granules should be washed and crushed, smears prepared from the crushed material, and appropriate media inoculated. Granules are most often seen in infections caused by N. brasiliensis or Actinomyces species but can also be seen in infections caused by other species of Nocardia (61). Adequate data are not available to allow using the presence of granules or granule color for precise species or even genus-level discrimination of the etiologic agent.

sect1.title: Nucleic Acid Detection
sect1.para: Several authors have reported the use of molecular methodologies for the detection ofNocardia species directly from clinical specimens. Targets include the 65-kDa HSP gene (182), the 16S rRNA gene (183, 184), and the secA1 gene (G. Fahle, personal communication, 2011). These techniques have the potential to provide rapid diagnosis of nocardiosis from samples exhibiting bacterial morphologies suggestive of this genus. Further assessment of these techniques will be needed to assess their sensitivities and overall clinical utility.

Isotalo et al. describe a method usingin situ hybridization for detection of Nocardia species in formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tissue specimens. Their procedure showed 77% sensitivity compared to that of standard histologic stains (185).

sect2.title: ISOLATION PROCEDURES
sect2.para: Blood agar, chocolate agar, brain heart infusion agar, Sabouraud dextrose agar, and Lowenstein-Jensen medium support the growth of most aerobic actinomycetes;D. congolensis may not grow on Sabouraud dextrose agar or Lowenstein-Jensen medium (7). Buffered charcoal yeast extract agar (BCYE) is particularly useful for the recovery of Nocardia species. Specimens from sterile sites or concentrated sterile body fluids can be inoculated directly onto these media. Specimens from respiratory sites, skin, and other potentially contaminated sites, such as mycetomas, should additionally be inoculated onto selective media, such as modified Thayer-Martin agar (186) and selective BCYE (containing polymyxin B, anisomycin, and either vancomycin or cefamandole) (187). Sabouraud agar with added chloramphenicol may not be useful, because it may also suppress the growth of some Nocardia species (188). A specialized medium for the recovery of R. equi using a Mueller-Hinton agar-based medium with added ceftazidime and novobiocin has been described (189). Members of the aerobic actinomycetes may also grow in liquid media (such as broth media for mycobacterial cultures), in which they may appear as solid granules. These particles may be captured with a pipette and plated to solid media. Such granules may also be crushed between two slides, dried, and stained (Y. Shea, personal communication, 2007).

Cultures for aerobic actinomycetes should be handled as fungal cultures, thus ensuring that the cultures will be incubated and regularly examined over an extended period. Two BCYE plates (for samples from sterile sites) or selective BCYE plates (for respiratory or other potentially contaminated sites) should be inoculated. One BCYE or selective BCYE plate should be incubated at 30°C and the other at 35°C, both in ambient air. It should be noted, however, thatStreptomyces species may show best growth at 25°C and that D. congolensis grows better and shows enhanced production of aerial hyphae in increased CO2 (7). Isolates of L. clevelandensis require incubation in atmospheres containing less than 1% oxygen tension (13). For all cultures, plates should be held for a minimum of 2 weeks, preferably for up to 3 weeks, and should be sealed to prevent dehydration.

A low-pH decontamination procedure has been successfully used for pretreatment of heavily contaminated specimens suspected of harboringNocardia species. The sample is diluted 1:10 in 0.2 M HCl–0.2 M KCl at pH 2.2, mixed, and allowed to stand for 3 to 5 min, after which it is inoculated onto selective and nonselective media (187). Improved recovery of Nocardia species from NaOH-NALC-treated specimens may result from a 15-min exposure to the decontaminating reagents, as is recommended for the recovery of mycobacteria (190, 191).

Aerobic actinomycetes have been recovered from blood using a variety of commercially available blood culture systems, including conventional two-bottle systems, biphasic bottles, automated blood culturing systems, and lysis-centrifugation systems. Using various blood culture systems, aerobic actinomycetes have been recovered after 3 to 19 days of incubation, which in some cases included the incubation times of terminal subcultures (160, 192). Studies employing newer blood culture systems have resulted in recommendations that extended incubation is no longer necessary (193); however, such studies have not established that such shorter incubation would generally be adequate for the isolation of aerobic actinomycetes. If bacteremia with a member of one of these genera is suspected, it is advisable to perform fungal blood cultures (for the extended incubation period, at least 3 weeks) or to perform terminal subcultures if the incubation period of routine blood cultures cannot be extended.

Plated cultures from all sources should be examined daily for the first week of incubation and then weekly thereafter, preferably using a dissecting microscope, which will allow detection of tiny colonies. Such microscopic examination is particularly important for specimens that contain contaminating microbiota, because an aerobic actinomycete can be quickly overgrown by more rapidly growing organisms. Care should also be exercised when Lowenstein-Jensen or Middlebrook media are examined for mycobacteria or when BCYE plates are examined forLegionella species, because Nocardia and other aerobic actinomycetes can grow on these media.

sect1.title: Microscopic Morphology
sect1.para: Evaluation of the Gram stain morphology of a suspected aerobic actinomycete should be the initial step in organism identification, because microscopic morphologies can vary among the genera (Table 1 and Fig. 3). A sufficient number of fields should be reviewed to allow determination of the most prevalent morphology and to detect the sometimes-rare branching forms. Care should be taken not to confuse perpendicular aligning of the organisms with true branching. Smears made from colonial growth of filamentous isolates may fragment and appear as bacillary or coccoid forms (61).

A properly prepared and carefully interpreted modified acid-fast smear can assist in the preliminary identification of the organism (Fig. 3F, G, I, J, and L). Quality control slides should be stained along with stains of colonies from cultures. With the modified acid-fast stain, the background should be blue; slides that have a pink background may be inadequately decolorized and should be repeated. The smear should be scanned for areas where individual bacterial cells can be seen. The acid-fast reaction of tightly packed clumps of organisms may not represent the true partially acid-fast nature of the cells; be wary of large clumps of cells which all appear to be acid-fast stain positive. Acid-fast cells will clearly be red; cells that stain purple or light pink may or may not be truly acid fast. A stain that shows an unambiguous positive acid-fast reaction may frequently show only a few clearly red cells, with a majority of blue cells. Frequently, only the beads appear acid-fast positive. If modified-acid-fast stain results are ambiguous, transfer of the organism to a lipid-rich medium, such as Lowenstein-Jensen medium or Middlebrook 7H11 agar (to increase the organism’s lipid content), and repeat staining may give a more clear-cut stain result. Acid fastness may become more evident as colonies age; the acid-fast reaction has been reported to be most reliable when the test is performed with colonies after 1 to 4 weeks of growth (194). Occasionally, coccoid forms of Streptomyces may appear to be partially acid fast; hyphae, however, are acid-fast negative. Because of the difficulties of interpretation of the modified acid-fast smear, results of this stain should be considered preliminary and must be used only in conjunction with results from other tests. In some cases, an isolate of a species that is considered to be modified-acid-fast stain positive may not give a positive stain reaction. If the microscopic and colonial morphology are consistent with an aerobic actinomycete, and if the isolate might be clinically significant, regardless of the acid-fast stain result, an attempt should be made to determine the identification of the isolate.

sect1.title: Slide Cultures
sect1.para: Slide cultures allow the evaluation of the morphology of some genera, such asAmycolatopsis and Nocardiopsis.
