Differences among the genera of aerobic actinomycetes in the growth characteristics seen on slide culture may be subtle; experience in recognizing these morphologic differences is required for correct interpretation of these tests. Further information on characteristic slide culture morphologies can be found in references 195 and 196.

sect1.title: Colonial Morphology
sect1.para: The colonial appearance of members of the aerobic actinomycetes is extremely variable among genera and even between isolates of the same species (Fig. 2). Environmental factors, such as growth medium, incubation temperature, air circulation, presence of CO2, and age of the culture, can affect the size and consistency of the colonies and the production of aerial hyphae (197). Some species produce a diffusible pigment that can vary from strain to strain. See Table 1 for information on specific colonial morphologies.

sect1.title: Aerial Hyphae
sect1.para: Aerial hyphae project away from the surface of the colony into the air but may not be apparent until 7 to 14 days for some species. The use of a dissecting microscope for observation of aerial hyphae is recommended.Nocardia and Streptomyces species usually produce abundant aerial hyphae that give the colonies their characteristic powdery or velvety appearance (Fig. 2C, E, and L); rare strains of Nocardia produce sparse or no aerial hyphae (Fig. 2D and G). Of the genera that are partially acid fast, only Nocardia species regularly produce aerial hyphae. For some genera of aerobic actinomycetes, the presence of spores and their relative numbers and arrangement on the aerial hyphae can also give some clue to genus identification (196).

sect1.title: Genus Assignment
sect1.para: To determine the genus of an unknown isolate, observation of microscopic and colonial morphology is especially important (Table 1 and Fig. 2 and 3). In assessing the characteristics of colonial growth, the presence or absence of aerial hyphae should be determined. Nocardia and Streptomyces species generally produce aerial hyphae, with other less commonly isolated genera also showing this morphologic trait (Table 1). Positive results of a carefully prepared and interpreted modified acid-fast smear combined with the presence of aerial hyphae help to distinguish Nocardia from the other genera.

Some recent reports have documented the inadequacy of traditional and commercial biochemical methods in identifying isolates correctly to the genus level. For example, isolates initially misidentified asR. equi using commercial test strips have on further study been found to belong to the genus Dietzia (53); isolates initially identified as Rhodococcus species have been found to belong to the genus Tsukamurella (166).

Laurent et al. describe a PCR-based method that allows differentiation of members of the genusNocardia from other genera of aerobic actinomycetes (198). It is not known if this method is satisfactory for the discrimination of newly described Nocardia species from other genera.
A real-time PCR assay that amplifies a 157-bp region of the 16S rRNA has been shown to provide discrimination ofTsukamurella species from other members of the aerobic actinomycetes (199).

The use of MALDI-TOF MS can also provide a preliminary indication of the identification of an aerobic actinomycete to the genus level, provided members of the genus are included in the profile database (see below).

sect1.title: Species Assignment
sect1.para: Given the increasing number of species of aerobic actinomycetes, the use of phenotypic or biochemical tests to obtain exact species or even genus-level identification has become impossible. In addition, phenotypic attributes may be unstable based on environmental and procedural variation. Among theNocardia, most species are nonreactive in most commercially available biochemicals, precluding the definitive identification of these isolates by these methods. For laboratories without molecular capabilities, assignment to the genus level should be attempted. When a precise identification is required for a significant patient isolate, molecular testing is generally required.

sect1.title: Biochemicals
sect1.para: Because of the increasing number of described species and the low discrimination power and small number of commercially available phenotypic tests, biochemical testing is not recommended for definitive identification of the aerobic actinomycetes.

sect1.title: Cell Wall and Cell Membrane Analysis
sect1.para: Analysis of the cell wall chemistry of the aerobic actinomycetes can aid in the identification of isolates to the genus level and is typically used in the initial description of new genera. Methodologies for the investigation of these chemical structures are generally available only in research or reference laboratories. Cell wall analysis is not useful for species-level identification. Please see earlier editions of thisManual for information on cell wall attributes of the aerobic actinomycetes (200).

sect1.title: Molecular Identification
sect1.para: Molecular techniques, particularly gene sequencing, are currently the only methods that can provide definitive identification of most isolates of aerobic actinomycetes. These methods have the added benefit of providing identifications in a fraction of the time needed for traditional biochemical tests and have been the driving force in the identification of novel species of all genera of aerobic actinomycetes.

sect2.title: PCR with Amplicon Detection
sect2.para: The use of PCR and amplicon detection by gel electrophoresis, with genus- or species-specific primers, enables the identification of aerobic actinomycetes that have unique gene regions. Regions of the 16S rRNA gene have been targeted for the genus-level identification ofNocardia (198), Pseudonocardia and Saccharopolyspora (201), Gordonia (202), and Nocardiopsis (203). PCR and amplicon detection of the 16S rRNA and choE genes (encoding a cholesterol oxidase) have also been used for the species-level identification of Rhodococcus species (204, 205).
More recently, real-time PCR-based high-resolution melting (HRM) analysis of thefusA-tuf intergenic region sequence was used for differentiation of the most common Nocardia species (206).

sect2.title: PCR with REA
sect2.para: PCR paired with restriction endonuclease analysis (REA) has been used for the identification of commonly isolatedNocardia species and has included evaluation of both the 16S rRNA and hsp65 genes (207–210). The procedure takes advantage of the presence of restriction endonuclease recognition sites within the variable regions of an organism’s gene sequence (208). However, because of the increasing number of recognized Nocardia species, and because these REA methodologies are able to detect alterations only within the relatively short restriction endonuclease recognition sequence, the usefulness of these techniques is limited to the identification of only a few species. For more information regarding the use of REA for the identification of Nocardia species, see previous editions of this Manual (211).

In addition to being used for the identification ofNocardia species, REA has been used for differentiation among numerous genera of aerobic actinomycetes and identification of some species of thermophilic actinomycetes (173, 212). It is likely that the usefulness of these procedures, too, will be increasingly limited as the number of recognized species within these genera increases.

sect2.title: Gene Sequencing
sect2.para: Gene sequencing has become a powerful and, currently, a necessary tool for the identification of isolates within this complex group of organisms. A recently updated Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) document MM18 discusses the 16S rRNA gene and other genes for identification of most common genera within the aerobic actinomycetes (213). Sequence analysis of the 16S rRNA gene has been used for the species-level identification of members of nearly all genera of the aerobic actinomycetes (45, 50, 59, 93, 144, 151, 162, 169, 174). While the 16S rRNA gene can provide identification at genus and sometimes species level, it may not reliably discriminate between closely related species (166, 214).

Several genes have been shown to discriminate adequately amongNocardia species. By far the most sequence information is available for the 16S rRNA gene sequences of members of this genus. See chapter 8, “Molecular Techniques,” of this Manual for a discussion of the phylogenetic attributes of this gene. The presence of a variable sequence region, located near the 5′ terminus of the gene (208), has made partial 16S rRNA sequencing of a 500-bp region of the gene a useful method for the identification of many Nocardia species. Cloud et al. (214) compared identifications obtained with a commercial 16S rRNA gene sequencing kit and an expanded database with results obtained using phenotypic identifications and with sequencing results from a 999-bp region of the same gene. The 500-bp-based identification of 94 clinical isolates representing 10 species showed 72% agreement with identifications obtained by phenotypic methods and 90% agreement with identifications obtained by sequencing a larger portion of the gene. At present, this commercial system is capable of distinguishing among the more commonly isolated Nocardia species and was also shown to be useful for the genus-level identification of Gordonia, Rhodococcus, Streptomyces, and Tsukamurella (121).

Sequencing a region of the 16S rRNA gene larger than 500 bp is necessary for the separation of some species ofNocardia that have identical or nearly identical sequences within the 500-bp region (for example, N. abscessus/N. asiatica/N. arthritidis, N. elegans/N. veterana, N. higoensis/N. shimofusensis, N. farcinica/N. kroppenstedtii, and N. brasiliensis/N. vulneris). In some instances, only a few base differences separate closely related species even when sequencing the full 16S rRNA gene, making an unambiguous identification of some isolates difficult (215).

An important component of identification of isolates by gene sequencing is the quality of the database used for sequence comparison. Users of any sequence database should be aware of the limitations inherent in that database. GenBank (NCBI National Center for Biotechnology Information;http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/) currently contains >40,000,000 entries for 16S sequences of various lengths and quality, derived from a diverse range of bacteria recovered from various clinical/environmental sources (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genbank); many of these entries contain only 16S sequences, but partial or entire genomes containing complete 16S sequences are increasingly being deposited. The drawback to the use of GenBank is that entries in the general database are not curated, and comparison of an unknown sequence with some poor-quality entries may result in an erroneous identification. Furthermore, the presence in GenBank of many redundant entries (i.e., identical sequences with the same species annotation) can even mask relevant matches to sequences of other species (216). GenBank contains a reference sequence (RefSeq) collection that contains nonredundant, annotated sequences that are curated by NCBI staff and collaborators (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/refseq). See Tables 2 and 3 for GenBank type strain sequences deemed to be reliable for the identification of Nocardia and other aerobic actinomycetes. For organisms not listed in those tables, laboratories may want to obtain specific type strains and determine the sequence of those isolates themselves to use as a comparison for unknown patient isolates. Proprietary 16S rRNA gene databases are available for the identification of Nocardia species and may be limited in the number of species represented and in the number of sequences of each species included. Cloud et al. expanded a commercial database with additional entries to obtain more reliable matches for query organisms (214). Other useful databases with curation for 16S rRNA gene sequences include the Ribosomal Database Project (RDP) (http://rdp.cme.msu.edu/), Greengenes Database Consortium (http://greengenes.lbl.gov/Download/Tutorial/Tutorial_19Dec05.pdf), and SILVA (http://www.arb-silva.de/aligner/) as well as commercially available databases (216, 217).

It is well known that the interspecies heterogeneity of genetically similarNocardia species as determined by 16S rRNA gene sequences can be quite low, making unambiguous identification of some isolates difficult, if not impossible, even when sequencing the full gene 16S rRNA. Examples include: several species within the N. nova complex, N. abscessus/N. asiatica/N. arthritidis (almost identical), N. exalbida/N. gamkensis (identical), N. brevicatena/N. paucivorans and (99.5% similarity) N. kruczakiae/N. veterana (99.8% similarity), N. testacea and N. sienata (2-base difference), and N. brasiliensis/N. vulneris (84, 112, 216). The CLSI document MM18 (2nd edition) indicates that for aerobic actinomycetes, greater than 99.6% similarity is required for identification to the species level with greater than 0.4% separation between different species (213). In addition, the document recommends a sequence similarity of 99.0 to 99.5% for identification to the genus level. We suggest that for accurate identification of some members of the N. nova complex (N. kruczakiae and N. veterana), sequence similarity of greater than 99.8% be employed (112).

The presence of multiple copies of the 16S rRNA gene in some isolates ofNocardia has been reported (218, 219). In these studies, the presence of up to 5 gene copies per organism was noted, and in some isolates, the various copies showed different base sequences. Sequence chromatograms from such isolates show multiple overlapping peaks at a particular position which remain unresolved even with repeat testing. Unfortunately, the type strains of several species contain multiple copies of the 16S rRNA gene (Table 3) (219). The sequences initially deposited in GenBank at the time the species were described do not indicate the presence of ambiguous bases in the 16S rRNA gene sequence and, therefore, do not reflect the presence of multiple gene copies. If the sequences of unknown isolates are compared to these type strain sequences, an acceptable match could not occur. There have been several reports of isolation of species for which the type strain contains multiple copies; in these reports, the authors have sometimes reported 100% agreement of their 16S rRNA gene sequences with that of the type strain, but given the presence of multiple differing copies, the resulting identification is questionable.

Other gene targets have been examined for their ability to discriminate among closely relatedNocardia species. Rodríguez-Nava et al. evaluated a 441-bp region of the hsp65 gene for its discriminatory ability for the identification of 44 Nocardia species (210). They found this gene to have more variable sequence regions than found in the 16S rRNA gene, resulting in more sequence dissimilarity among species. This level of sequence heterogeneity will allow discrimination of some species that are very similar by 16S rRNA gene sequencing.

ThesecA1 gene is a housekeeping gene that codes for the SecA1 protein. This protein is essential for the export of proteins across the bacterial cytoplasmic membrane (220). Sequence analysis of a 468-bp region of the secA1 gene has been shown to give good discrimination among Nocardia species (113). In a study of 30 type or reference strains of clinical significance, clear differentiation of all species was obtained. In addition, alignment of the deduced amino acid sequence (156 amino acid residues) showed good separation of all type and reference strains and eliminated some within-species microheterogeneities seen in the gene sequences. The deduced amino acid sequences of 38 of 40 clinical isolates tested were identical to that of the type strain of the species to which that isolate was assigned. Kang et al. reported that the analysis of the gyrB gene and the secA1 gene sequences of Gordonia species allows greater discrimination among species than does the 16S rRNA gene (221). The secA1 gene has also been used to identify members of the genus Tsukamurella (222, 223).

In a study of 120Nocardia isolates (10 ATCC strains and 110 clinical isolates), Kong et al. noted some discordant identifications with the secA1 genes from clinical isolates compared to the 5′ ends of 606-bp 16S rRNA gene sequences, especially with isolates identified as N. nova on the basis of 16S rRNA sequences (224). With the secA1 gene target, the authors noted a high level of intraspecies diversity, especially among N. cyriacigeorgica, N. farcinica, N. nova, and N. veterana. The authors suggest that the diversity of this gene may make it a useful target for epidemiologic evaluations. However, the lack of secA1 sequences in the public databases for newly described species makes identification of such species using this gene difficult.

ThegyrB gene may also be a useful target for the identification of Nocardia species, although it has been noted to be present in multiple copies in some strains (225). This gene encodes the β-subunit of DNA gyrase, a type II topoisomerase. In an evaluation of 56 Nocardia type strains, Takeda et al. (226) noted that with the gyrB gene, the interspecies variation ranged from 82.4 to 99.9% (270 to 2 base differences) in sequences of 1,200 bp. The 16S rRNA gene sequences of the same species (as determined from GenBank entries) showed 94.4 to 100% interspecies variation, indicating that sequencing of the gyrB gene may better enable the discrimination of some closely related species. Phylogenetic trees created using this gene were similar to trees created using the 16S rRNA gene. This gene also clearly discriminated Nocardia species from other related genera.

Carrasco et al. reported that thegyrB and the rpoB genes display varying degrees of inter- and intraspecies microheterogeneities that provide better species differentiation of Nocardia species than does analysis of the 16S rRNA gene (227). The rpoB gene is an additional housekeeping gene that codes for the β-subunit of RNA polymerase. In a study of 29 isolates of N. abscessus, analysis of the 16S rRNA gene showed a single sequence type, while gyrB and rpoB sequences showed 14 and 18 sequence types, respectively. Similar results were obtained with isolates of N. cyriacigeorgica and N. farcinica (227). The use of these genes may also provide useful information regarding strain discrimination. However, Tamura et al. (225) noted that some Nocardia strains may harbor multiple copies of the rpoB gene, which may complicate sequence analysis. Finally, Sánchez-Herrera et al. described the use of a 386-bp fragment of the sodA gene (encoding the enzyme superoxide dismutase) for the identification of Nocardia spp. and compared its performance to the 16S rRNA gene, hsp65, secA1, gyrB, and rpoB (228).

Sequence analysis of various other genes has been shown to be useful for the identification of other genera of aerobic actinomycetes. For the identification ofGordonia species, Kang et al. reported that the analysis of the gyrB gene sequence demonstrated more discrimination power than analysis of either the 16S rRNA gene or the secA1 gene (221). The use of the groEL gene (HSP 60) for the identification of Tsukamurella species provided intraspecies variation of 91.1 to 98.2% compared to 96.7 to 99.9% similarity of the 16S rRNA gene (229). The choE gene, encoding a cholesterol oxidase, has been used for specific detection and identification of Rhodococcus equi (204).

sect2.title: Multilocus Sequence Analysis (MLSA)
sect2.para: For some genera such asNocardia, sequence analysis of more than one gene may be useful for unambiguous identification of a clinical isolate and for the recognition of an unusual species. Rodríguez-Nava et al. (210) noted that a combined analysis using both the 16S rRNA and the hsp gene resolved identification inconsistencies of some Nocardia isolates. Multilocus sequence analysis (MLSA) using concatenated sequences of 3 or more housekeeping genes has been increasingly used to provide higher accuracy and discriminatory power in molecular identification of Nocardia spp., to gain information on taxonomic delineations, and more recently to help reconcile discrepancies between single target sequence-based and MALDI-TOF MS-based identification results (230–232).

In 2010, McTaggart et al. reported the usefulness of MLSA for identification and similarity studies ofNocardia species and noted that MLSA may surpass the use of DNA-DNA hybridization as the gold standard for bacterial taxonomy (232). The authors created sequence-based phylogenetic clusters using concatenated partial sequences of five genes—gyrB, the 16S rRNA gene, secA1, hsp65, and rpoB—in a study of 36 type and reference strains and 190 clinical isolates. The results showed that 71.3% of the clinical isolates clustered with type strains and were thus considered to be identified to the species level. The authors found that when sequences of individual genes were evaluated, the resulting identification differed from that obtained using MLSA. This was especially evident for sequences targeting hsp65 and rpoB. The authors noted that the sequences from multiple genes appeared to “buffer” the effect of discrepant alleles in the sequences of the individual genes. Results using a four-locus (gyrB, 16S rRNA gene, secA1, hsp65) or a three-locus (gyrB, 16S rRNA, secA1) scheme were nearly as reliable as results using a five-locus scheme. More recently, the same three-locus scheme of concatenated gyrB–16S rRNA–secA1 sequences was shown to provide high accuracy and discrimination of 46 clinical Nocardia species (233).

While MLSA does provide higher accuracy in identification of isolates, it has limitations. (i) It does not resolve identification of some isolates in some challenging species, groups of species, or complexes (i.e.,N. abscessus/N. arthritidis-like, or species within the N. transvalensis complex). (ii) It is cumbersome for many clinical laboratories to sequence four or five genes to identify clinical isolates of Nocardia spp. Therefore, as discussed above, abbreviated MLSA schemes with three (or even two) targets have been proposed (i.e., 16S rRNA, gyrB, and secA) (222) which provide species (or complex) assignment for the majority of isolates or can raise suspicion on occurrence of a novel species. (iii) Because few quality databases exist and in-house validation is necessary (with additional genes), few laboratories can afford the time and expense required to perform MLSA.

Xu et al. used whole-genome sequencing to characterize the genomic diversity, taxonomic classification, and evolutionary relationships of the genusNocardia. Horizontal gene transfer was highlighted as a major evolutionary driver of genetic diversity within the genus. Based on the phylogenomic analysis, most species were assigned five main phylogroups, composed of 11 to 30 species. Furthermore, the authors suggested 28 potentially new species and reclassified several strains (234).

More recently, next-generation sequencing has also been used for direct detection and identification ofNocardia spp. from clinical samples with a turnaround time of 2 days compared to with an average of 7.5 days by culture (235).

sect1.title: Proteomics
sect1.para: MALDI-TOF MS is increasingly used to identify isolates of numerous genera and species of bacteria, especially isolates from clinical specimens. Identifications are based on proteomic profiling by mass spectral analysis, and results obtained from individual isolates are compared to spectra included in databases. Many studies have been performed to determine the usefulness of MALDI-TOF MS for the identification of members of the aerobic actinomycetes. Generally, results obtained from the use of this technology show good correlation with reference methods for the rapid and accurate identification ofNocardia species. However, while some species are easily identified (i.e., N. brasiliensis), for others identification has only been shown to extend to the complex level (N. abscessus complex, N. brevicatena-N. paucivorans complex, N. nova complex, and N. transvalensis complex) (236–238). Identification of uncommon Nocardia species remains a challenge. Other publications have emphasized the need for robust spectra libraries to ensure accurate identifications of other members of the aerobic actinomycetes, including isolates belonging to Gordonia, Rhodococcus, Streptomyces, and Tsukamurella (238–241).

The role of cultural characteristics, including media and incubation time, that may affect results obtained with MALDI-TOF MS analysis has been evaluated. Published studies indicate that growth from glucose yeast extract agar provides more accurate results than growth from brain heart infusion agar for isolates ofGordonia, Nocardia, Rhodococcus, and Tsukamurella (242), and that testing earlier growth of Nocardia species may reduce the influence of colony characteristics that vary with incubation time, such as pigment and the presence of aerial hyphae (237). Pasciak et al. recommend an incubation time of 24 hours for Rhodococcus species, 48 hours for isolates of Nocardia spp. and Tsukamurella spp., and 72 hours for isolates of Gordonia spp. prior to testing with MALDI-TOF MS (242). CLSI M58 guidelines state that each laboratory should refer to manufacturer’s recommendations for a list of media that have been demonstrated to be compatible with their MALDI-TOF MS instrument type and database and should evaluate other media for any potential influence on identification scores and accuracy (243).

When developing custom, user-built identificationNocardia databases to supplement commercial databases, laboratories should include spectra from well-characterized organisms, including the type strain and other reference strains, with the goal of achieving successful identification of the most common species/complexes for that institution. Laboratories should also be aware of the extraction method used to develop the database, as superior performance has been noted when the same extraction method is used for both database development and testing unknown isolates (243).

One area of concern regarding MALDI-TOF MS technology includes the methods used for protein extraction. Members of the aerobic actinomycetes, like species of mycobacteria, possess complex cell walls that resist disruption, and any method used to break up the cell wall and extract proteins must maintain the hydrophobic and hydrophilic properties of the proteins (244). While some publications describe the feasibility of using direct spotting of intact isolates for analysis (239), the direct spotting technique used for other aerobic bacteria has been shown by others to be inadequate for preparation of aerobic actinomycetes for MALDI-TOF MS analysis (236, 238, 240). Verroken et al. describe an extraction method in which Nocardia isolates are boiled for 30 minutes (245); however, it has been noted that the boiling process complicates protein identification because of the addition of formyl groups to the extracted proteins (246). Recent publications describe extraction methods based on mechanical break-up of organisms with the use of either microbeads and bead beating or vortexing; both methods include an ethanol extraction (236, 240). Additionally, improved identification may be obtained by duplicate spotting and re-extraction of isolates for which acceptable identifications were not initially obtained (236).

Blosser et al. reported a three-center study using one commercial system and comparing identifications obtained with three protein libraries and the ability of those libraries to provide accurate identification of 150Nocardia isolates belonging to 19 species or species complexes, as compared to results obtained from gene sequencing (236). Their results indicate that the highest percentage of correct identifications was obtained when spectra were compared to a combination of the three libraries, highlighting the need for libraries that contain a sufficient range of the spectra obtainable from different isolates of a particular species. Several studies on this commercial system have demonstrated the limitations of the ability of commercial databases to provide accurate identifications with variable (between 0% and 47.3%) agreement to sequencing methods (230, 236, 243). With the use of in-house libraries developed with custom spectra identification, agreement improved to up to 95% (236, 238, 243). Overall, successful identification was achieved with common species including N. brasiliensis, N. cyriacigeorgica, N. farcinica, N. nova complex, and N. otitidiscaviarum. Variable results were obtained for N. transvalensis complex, N. pseudobrasiliensis, N. abscessus complex, and N. beijingensis. As expected, uncommon species with limited or no representation in the databases were the most challenging (i.e., N. aobensis, N. testaceae, Nocardia spp.) (236, 237). In addition to updating RUO libraries, the manufacturer has since made available an IVD database including five commonly isolated Nocardia taxa.

A total of 46Nocardia spp. strains (belonging to 12 species) were used in the evaluation of a second commercial system yielding 91% correct species level identification (239). Girard et al. (244, 247) discussed the development and validation of a Nocardia MALDI-TOF MS database to be released in an updated database for a third commercial system. A challenge set of 164 strains yielded 95% correct identification of claimed species. The platform successfully identified the common species N. cyriacigeorgica, N. farcinica, N. nova/N. nova complex, and N. otitidiscaviarum and also the less common species N. abscessus and N. beijingensis. However, while most N. brasiliensis isolates tested (6/7) were correctly identified, one strain was misidentified as N. farcinica (reason unclear). In addition, N. transvalensis could not be tested due to lack of strains. Recent work using this commercial system reported 76% (236/312) Nocardia isolates correctly identified to the species level, with an additional 44 (14%) correctly identified to the complex level. Species within the N. nova and N. transvalensis complexes could not always be differentiated (248). More recently, Durand et al. evaluated the same commercial system and database on 222 DNA sequence-defined Nocardia spp. including 19 isolates from species not in the database. N. farcinica and N. cyriacigeorgica showed 100% correct identification regardless of culture media type tested. Respotting extracted material and/or performing a new extraction increased the number of correct identifications by 20 and 13%, yielding 87% and 91% correct identification for isolates grown on bromocresol purple agar and Columbia agar with 5% sheep blood, respectively. Finally, strains from species not represented in the database yielded no identification (for N. puris and N. goodfellowii) or misidentification within the same phylogenetic complex (for N. arthritidis, N. cerradoensis, and N. altamirensis) (249).

sect2.title: TYPING SYSTEMS
sect2.para: For the aerobic actinomycetes, reports on strain typing methodologies are limited to studies ofNocardia, Rhodococcus, and Tsukamurella species. For Nocardia, there is no consensus on the best method for performing strain typing. Lack of reproducibility and/or insufficient differences among strains are common difficulties seen with most methods. In addition, interpretive criteria for the various methods are undefined.

AmongNocardia species, N. farcinica is most frequently implicated in infection outbreaks. Kachi et al. used randomly amplified polymorphic DNA (RAPD) to identify a suspected nosocomial outbreak of N. farcinica (250). In contrast, Kalpoe et al. reported irreproducible and unsatisfactory results by RAPD and pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) analyses, respectively, and favored the use of amplified fragment length polymorphism (AFLP) (251).

MLSA schemes used for identification ofNocardia spp. can also provide typing information for species showing high intraspecies strain diversity, such as N. cyriacigeorgica, with strains clustering in three distinct subgroups. This approach is less informative for species with lower diversity such as N. farcinica.

sect2.title: SEROLOGIC TESTS
sect2.para: There have been no recent publications (since 1988) describing serologic methods for the diagnosis of infections caused by aerobic actinomycetes.

sect2.title: ANTIMICROBIAL SUSCEPTIBILITIES
sect2.para: Susceptibility testing should be performed on all isolates ofNocardia and other aerobic actinomycetes thought to be of possible clinical significance. CLSI has published a revised approved standard for susceptibility testing of both mycobacteria and aerobic actinomycetes (234) and an additional document listing current MIC breakpoints and quality control strains and acceptable ranges (252). The recommended procedure for susceptibility testing of Nocardia and the other aerobic actinomycetes is broth microdilution; panels containing the appropriate dilutions of antimicrobials specifically active against these genera are commercially available, but at the time of this writing, none is FDA cleared for use in the United States. The CLSI document outlines methods for inoculum preparation, panel inoculation, incubation, and result interpretation (253). For Nocardia species, panels are read after 3 to 5 days of incubation, with the incubation duration dependent on the species being tested. Antimicrobial agents recommended for primary susceptibility testing of all aerobic actinomycete genera include amikacin, amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, clarithromycin, imipenem, linezolid, minocycline, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, and tobramycin. Agents to be considered for secondary testing include cefepime, cefotaxime, and doxycycline. The CLSI document lists both the breakpoints and the interpretive criteria for all drugs to be tested for Nocardia isolates; according to the CLSI document, both an MIC and an interpretation of the MIC result should be provided in the report to the physician (252, 253). The document also indicates that the breakpoints listed for Nocardia species can be used for other aerobic actinomycetes, but should be reported as tentative, pending accumulation of further information on these drug/organism combinations (252).

In 2012, the results of a multisite reproducibility study of the broth microdilution method forNocardia spp. were published (254). Six U.S. testing sites with various levels of experience in performing susceptibility testing reported results for five frequently recovered Nocardia spp. using a commercially prepared panel. Results indicated that interlaboratory reproducibility was related to the antimicrobial being tested; ceftriaxone, imipenem, sulfamethoxazole, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, and tigecycline results were found to be the least reproducible among different laboratories. Results for ceftriaxone with N. cyriacigeorgica and N. wallacei were most problematic and should probably not be reported for these species. To avoid problems with result reproducibility, MIC results for the Nocardia and other aerobic actinomycetes (i.e., the more rapidly growing species) should be examined for growth at 48 hours. If growth is adequate, the MICs should be read at this time (253).

Sulfonamides remain the mainstay of treatment for many nocardial infections other than those involving the central nervous system. A sulfonamide is often used in combination with other antimicrobial agents because of the historicalin vitro susceptibility of Nocardia isolates to sulfonamides and because of a long history of the clinical effectiveness of these drugs if administered in adequate doses (254, 255). Several recent reports have indicated an increase in resistance to the sulfonamides among Nocardia spp. Ameen et al. reported that 8 of 19 patients in Mexico with actinomycetomas caused by Nocardia failed sulfonamide treatment; the authors proposed that sulfonamides should be used only for limited actinomycotic disease of comparatively short duration and only for those patients with actinomycetomas who are at low risk for visceral dissemination (256). In 2010, Uhde et al. reported that 61% of Nocardia isolates submitted for susceptibility testing to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) from 1995 to 2004 were resistant to sulfamethoxazole, and 42% were resistant to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (257). The authors stated that their results may not represent the resistance profile of all U.S. isolates, because only organisms recovered from patients with severe infections or from patients with treatment failures may have been submitted for testing. The authors also indicated that they did not receive information on any possible preinfection antibiotic prophylaxis or on clinical outcome. Larruskain et al. reported in 2011 that the majority of N. farcinica isolates from northern Spain were resistant to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (258). In contrast, results from Taiwan indicate that only 2% of 138 Nocardia isolates tested over an 11-year period were sulfonamide resistant (259). In response to the report from the CDC on sulfonamide resistance in the United States, Brown-Elliott et al. reported a retrospective analysis of 552 Nocardia isolates recovered and tested at six U.S. laboratories, among which only 2% were resistant to sulfonamides (260). The authors proposed that reports of increased resistance may be related to the difficulties in interpretation of sulfonamide broth dilution tests, the lack of a recommended Nocardia species quality control organism, and the lack of proficiency testing programs to ensure accurate interpretation. There are limited data to indicate the in vivo result of sulfonamide treatment in cases of in vitro resistance. The multisite broth microdilution study published in 2012 noted a significant lack of reproducibility among testing sites for the sulfonamides (254). Of a total of 1,681 replicate sulfonamide MIC results for five species (one isolate each of N. brasiliensis, N. cyriacigeorgica, N. farcinica, N. nova, and N. wallacei determined by previous testing to be susceptible to sulfonamides), 14.6% of results indicated resistance to sulfamethoxazole or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Since criteria for inoculum preparation and assay performance were similar at all testing sites, the authors noted that the most likely explanation for this lack of reproducibility with these drugs is the difficulty of determining the endpoint, which is defined as the dilution that results in 80% inhibition compared to growth in the control well. Interestingly, only 1.7% of 296 concurrently run disk diffusion tests using the same isolates indicated resistance to sulfamethoxazole. The authors propose that when performing broth microdilution tests for sulfonamides, a disk diffusion test using Gantrisin (not trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) be performed for validation of the MIC result. The inoculated disk diffusion plate may also be useful for checking the inoculum concentration (254). The CLSI document states that isolates showing a discrepancy between the broth microdilution and disk diffusion tests for sulfonamides should be retested or referred to a reference laboratory for testing (253).

The 2012 multicenter study also highlighted additional difficulties that may be encountered in the setup and interpretation of broth microdilution tests forNocardia (254). Preparation of an adequate inoculum is an important concern; the clumping nature of Nocardia isolates often prevents the preparation of an adequately homogeneous inoculum suspension. The current CLSI document suggests the use of a “pellet pestle” to assist in creating a dense suspension with a minimum of organism clumps (253). In addition, the use of a nephelometer to standardize the inoculum suspension is recommended to provide an appropriately dense inoculum (253). However, even with careful inoculum preparation, resulting colony counts prepared using traditional spread plate techniques may not accurately represent the actual organism concentration in the inoculum (254). The CLSI document recommends evaluation of a Mueller-Hinton plate inoculated as for a Kirby-Bauer disk diffusion test to evaluate the adequacy of the inoculum (253). Because endpoint determination for Nocardia spp. is more technically challenging than for other organisms, the multisite study report recommends that technical staff should become familiar with endpoint determinations as illustrated in the CLSI M24 guidelines, especially for the sulfonamides. Additional recommendations to improve susceptibility testing results include thorough training of technical staff in inoculum and panel preparation, comparison of results with expected results for a particular species (as noted in the current CLSI document), the testing of an appropriate quality control strain (N. nova ATCC BAA-2227 was recommended [254]), and participation in proficiency testing with another laboratory. The multisite study also recommends referral of any isolate to a reference laboratory if the susceptibility pattern obtained is different from the expected result for that organism (254).

In a study of 51 clinical isolates ofNocardia spp. and 12 other species of aerobic actinomycetes, Lowman and Aithma compared results from the Etest to results obtained by broth microdilution. Results from the Etest showed only 46.2 to 81.6% agreement within ±1 dilution and 67.5 to 100% categorical agreement with broth microdilution. There were very major errors reported with the Etest for the more rarely isolated species. The authors concluded that the Etest is not an acceptable alternative to broth microdilution for the aerobic actinomycetes and note specific problems with inoculum preparation and reading/interpretation of the test (261).

Table 4 and the current CLSI document M62 list the typical susceptibility patterns of the most commonly isolated Nocardia spp. (252). Two major studies have been applied to update the antimicrobial susceptibility patterns of the most commonly isolated Nocardia spp. noted in Table 4 (262, 263).

The changes are not unexpected, due to larger numbers ofNocardia being studied and more Nocardia species being described. Since the original table was based on small numbers of isolates and most from a single reference laboratory, a few changes have been made in the data presented here, including changes from “variable” (V) to “susceptible” (S) or “resistant/intermediate” (R/I) and conversion of susceptibility of minocycline in N. brasiliensis to mostly R/I.

Additionally, data for the majority of isolates ofN. otitidiscaviarum have changed from S for ciprofloxacin to R/I based on two recent large studies (262, 263). A retrospective analysis from France used the agar disk diffusion method, which has not been recommended by the CLSI, to study 793 isolates of Nocardia. Major discrepancies with the broth microdilution results included several “organism/antimicrobial combinations” such as N. transvalensis complex/amoxicillin-clavulanate, amikacin, imipenem, and minocycline, N. abscessus complex/imipenem, N. cyriacigeorgica/minocycline, and N. nova complex/minocycline (264).

Two smaller studies (265, 266), a 2020 broth microdilution susceptibility study of 270 isolates in Australia and a 2017 study in China of 28 isolates, were in agreement with the previous data, with one discrepancy in the Wei et al. study in which 3/3 isolates of N. brasiliensis were reported as susceptible to imipenem (266). Given the small number of isolates tested (<10 for some species), the thought process is that resistance would likely be apparent with more isolates tested, since all other reported studies showed ≥85% resistance to imipenem with N. brasiliensis (253, 262, 263).

An additional study in 2016 analyzed 170 isolates ofNocardia against meropenem and ertapenem. Among the most commonly encountered species, the N. nova complex and the N. abscessus complex had MIC50 values of ≤2 μg/ml for meropenem and ertapenem. The other common species, including N. cyriacigeorgica, N. brasiliensis, N. farcinica, and the N. transvalensis complex, had MIC50 values of ≥8 μg/ml for both agents. The CLSI has not addressed testing or MIC breakpoints for meropenem or ertapenem against Nocardia (267).

There is limited information in the literature regarding susceptibility testing of members of the aerobic actinomycetes other thanNocardia. Erol et al. reported MIC90 results of testing isolates of Amycolatopsis species from cases of nocardioform placentitis in horses using a commercially available panel (268). There are no standardized breakpoints or interpretive categories for members of this genus.

Isolates in the generaDietzia tend to be susceptible to a broad range of antimicrobials, and at present, there is no clear evidence that susceptibility can be predicted by species identification (53).

Moser et al. reported that 13 clinical isolates ofGordonia polyisoprenivorans were susceptible to amikacin, amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, ampicillin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, imipenem, linezolid, and vancomycin using the CLSI-recommended procedure. Of those 13 isolates, 8 were reported to be resistant to sulfamethoxazole (269).

An evaluation of the antimicrobial susceptibility results for 12 clinical isolates ofKroppenstedtia eburnea indicated that the isolates had low MICs to a variety of antimicrobial agents, with the exception of clarithromycin, to which the isolates were resistant, with MICs of ≥32 μg/ml (60).

ForR. equi, a combination of antimicrobials is generally used for the treatment of infections. Agents used include aminoglycosides, erythromycin, imipenem, quinolones, rifampin, and vancomycin. The current CLSI M24 document recommends that a regular Gram-positive panel be inoculated (if such panels include rifampin and vancomycin, critical antimicrobials for this species). Breakpoints for Staphylococcus aureus should be used for rifampin and vancomycin; for all other drugs, the MIC breakpoints for Nocardia should be employed. Results can be read after 24 hours of incubation, and results should be reported as “tentative” pending accumulation of more information. Linezolid may also be efficacious (151). Some rifampin-resistant strains with rpoB gene mutations have been reported (270).

Drug susceptibility testing of isolates ofS. rugosus may require the use of Middlebrook 7H9 broth, because the use of cation-adjusted Mueller-Hinton broth may provide insufficient growth (271). Using breakpoints recommended for Nocardia spp. and for rapidly growing mycobacteria, Butler et al. found that the S. rugosus isolates were susceptible to imipenem, rifabutin, sulfamethoxazole, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and resistant or intermediate to amikacin, amoxicillin-clavulanate, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, clarithromycin, linezolid, minocycline, and tobramycin (271).

In a study of the susceptibility of 92Streptomyces spp. from clinical specimens, 100% of those tested were found to be susceptible to amikacin and linezolid, 77% to minocycline, 67% to imipenem, and 51% to clarithromycin and amoxicillin-clavulanate (272).

Liu et al. recently reported susceptibility results forTsukamurella pulmonis, T. spumae, and T. tyrosinosolvens using a short-incubation antimicrobial susceptibility testing system and noted that these three species were susceptible to amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, ciprofloxacin, moxifloxacin, and linezolid. T. tyrosinosolvens and T. spumae were reported to be susceptible to sulfamethoxazole, while T. pulmonis was reported to be resistant (166). The current CLSI document indicates that susceptibility testing for Tsukamurella spp. may be read after 48 h of incubation (253).

Using breakpoints established forNocardia spp., susceptibility testing of the W. muralis isolate indicated that the isolate was susceptible to amoxicillin-clavulanate, cefotaxime, imipenem, ciprofloxacin, tobramycin, gentamicin, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (170).

For aerobic actinomycetes other thanNocardia spp., CLSI document M24 indicates that the breakpoints for Nocardia may tentatively be used and that these should be reported as “tentative pending the accumulation of further information” (253).

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: The aerobic actinomycetes are widespread in the environment. Therefore, particularly when an aerobic actinomycete is isolated in culture in small amounts without having been visualized in the direct patient specimen, it may be impossible for the laboratory to determine if the isolate is the result of specimen or laboratory contamination, patient colonization, or actual infection. Some indication of the quantity of the organism present should be given for any isolate of an aerobic actinomycetes. Discussion between the clinical and laboratory staff is extremely useful for selection of additional patient specimens and laboratory procedures for determination of the clinical significance of an isolate from a given patient. (See the “Clinical Significance” section of this chapter for information on species known to cause human disease. Additionally, seeTables 2 and 3 for information on the frequency of isolation of species known to be clinically significant.) Identification of an organism to the genus level may help determine its significance. However, even for accurate genus assignment, molecular methods may need to be employed. In some cases, genus-level identification (if possible) suffices.

When an isolate is reported to the species level, the laboratory should be certain that clinicians are aware of the reliability of the identification method used. Reports should indicate how the isolate was identified. Precise identification can be achieved only by gene sequencing or proteomic analysis using an expanded database; if identification is obtained by other methods, the report should indicate that the identification is presumptive. Susceptibility results should be reported for isolates considered to be clinically significant. For accurate determination of both identification and susceptibility results, referral to a laboratory with expertise in working with these organisms may be necessary.

ForNocardia spp., isolates may be identified and reported at a “complex” or “group” level. These identification methods may cluster species based on the characteristic method that is used for categorization. Nocardia spp. have been classified into complexes based on various characteristics such as their antimicrobial susceptibility pattern, their various gene sequences, and their MALDI-TOF MS profile (see above). When laboratories report results of clinical isolates of Nocardia at a complex or group level, it is important that reports be explicit in describing the basis for the complex determination and indicate the organisms that are considered to be included in the complex or group.

For susceptibility testing, a number of species are grouped into complexes based on the predicted antimicrobial susceptibility patterns. Based on susceptibility test results, members of the genusNocardia can be grouped into the following complexes: the N. nova complex, the N. transvalensis complex, and the N. brevicatena/N. paucivorans complex (253).

Nocardia isolates may be clustered into a single species complex based on the variation of gene sequences observed among members of a certain species. Patel et al. noted variation in the 65-kDa HSP gene and in 16S rRNA gene sequences of a collection of N. otitidiscaviarum isolates and determined that the species may actually include a complex of isolates with closely related species (121). Likewise, Schlaberg et al. noted the heterogeneity of the hsp and 16S rRNA genes of isolates belonging to the species N. cyriacigeorgica (95). Various distance matrix methodologies have been used to analyze the relatedness of the 16S rRNA gene of isolates belonging to a particular species and have shown that while differences exist in the gene sequences of those isolates, most isolates of a species cluster around a “centroid” sequence (214, 273). This heterogeneity of isolates of a single species has prompted some to refer to species such as N. otitidiscaviarum as a species complex (61). Evaluation of sequence similarity trees of Nocardia spp. shows that there are some species that are closely related based on the similarity of their gene sequences. Complex groupings based on similarities of gene sequences correspond in some cases with groupings based on antimicrobial susceptibility patterns, specifically for the N. nova complex, the N. transvalensis complex, the N. brevicatena/N. paucivorans complex, and the N. farcinica complex (215).

Whenever a laboratory isolates an aerobic actinomycete for which sequencing indicates that the organism has been rarely isolated, the circumstances surrounding the isolation of the organism should be carefully evaluated to assess its potential clinical significance, and a search of recent literature might be conducted to determine what is already established regarding pathogenicity and antibiotic susceptibility for that species. For such searches, the LPSN and PubMed may be good starting points; care should be taken to consider current nomenclature and taxonomy as stated by the LPSN. The report of a rare or unusual species should be accompanied by a brief summary of whatever is known regarding its clinical significance. In circumstances where identification and/or susceptibility of the organism is difficult, the isolate should be sent to a qualified reference laboratory (177).
